The Komodo dragon has other names .
The Komodo dragon ( Varanus komodoensis ) is a species of lizard that lives in the Indonesian islands of Komodo , Rincah , Flores , Gili Motang , and Gili Dasami .
It also has a long , yellow , forked tongue .
The scales around its ears , lips , chin , and bottoms of the feet may have three or more of these connections .
They take around three to five years to mature and may live as long as fifty years .
Western scientists first saw Komodo dragons in 1910 .
It can also be called the Komodo Monitor or the Komodo Island Monitor by some scientists , but this is not very common .
The Komodo dragon is able to see in color , but has trouble seeing objects that do not move .
This creates a good environment for the dangerous bacteria that live in its mouth .
Young Komodo dragons live in trees , where they are safe from adult Komodo dragons and other animals that might eat them .
The Komodo dragon uses its tongue to taste and smell like many other reptiles .
Komodo National Park was made to help protect Komodo dragons .
Its saliva is red because its gums almost completely cover its teeth .
It has a tail as long as its body .
On June 4 , 2007 , a Komodo dragon attacked an eight-year-old boy on Komodo Island .

It includes the interaction and maintenance of nuclear fission systems and components such as nuclear reactors , nuclear power plants , and nuclear weapons .
Nuclear engineering is a field of engineering dealing with application of atomic nuclei breakdown and other sub-atomic physics , based on the principles of nuclear physics .
Nuclear engineering also includes the study of nuclear fusion , medical and other applications of radiation , radiation safety , heat transport , nuclear fuel and other related technologies , nuclear proliferation , and the effect of radioactive waste or radioactivity on the environment .

Indeed , two very large nearby galaxies , Maffei 1 and Maffei 2 , were discovered in the Zone of Avoidance by Paolo Maffei by their infrared emission in 1968 .
The Zone of Avoidance ( ZOA ) is the area of the night sky that is obscured by our own galaxy , the Milky Way .
In more recent years , many projects have attempted to bridge the gap in our knowledge caused by the Zone of Avoidance .
As a result , optical galaxy catalogues are usually very incomplete close to the galactic plane .
However , the effects of the Zone drops at longer wavelengths , such as the infrared , and the Milky Way is effectively transparent at radio wavelengths .
Examples of galaxies detected from their HI emission include Dwingeloo 1 and Dwingeloo 2 .
Even so , about 10 % of the sky remains difficult to survey because extragalactic objects ( for example , distant galaxies ) can be confused with stars in the Milky Way .
Projects to survey the Zone of Avoidance at radio wavelengths have detected many galaxies that could not be detected in the infrared .
Surveys in the infrared have given us a more complete picture of the extragalactic sky .
Dust and stars in the plane of the Milky Way ( the galactic plane ) obstruct our view of about 20 % of the sky at visible wavelengths .

''

Lionel Edmund Rose MBE ( 21 June 1948 - 8 May 2011 ) was an Australian boxer .
In 1970 , at the age of 15 , Rose won the Australian amateur flyweight title .
Numata beat Rose by a 15-round decision .
Roy was a skilled fighter who competed in local house shows .
After this , he was rematched with Singtong Por Tor , whom he had previously beaten in a 12-round decision .

Five months later , he returned to Inglewood , where he faced Rubén Olivares on 22 August .
It made Rose a national hero in Australia , particularly among Aboriginal Australians .
He was born at Jacksons Track , and lived in the town of Warragul .
On 6 December , he fought against Chucho Castillo in Inglewood , California .
Rose continued boxing after his defeat against Olivares .
At the age of 10 , Rose was given a pair of gloves by his teacher , Ian Hawkins .
On 10 October 1970 , he beat future world lightweight champion Itshimatsu Suzuki in a 10-round decision .
As a professional boxer , Rose had a record of 42 wins and 11 losses , with 12 wins by knockout .
On 2 July of that year , Rose returned to Tokyo to defend his title against Takao Sakurai .
However , after losing four of his six matches , including one against Rafael Limón , he decided to retire forever .
Along the way he was helped by Jack and Shirley Rennie .
He fought Laurie Ny in Christchurch , New Zealand .
He beat Harada in a 15-round decision .
After this , Rose challenged Fighting Harada for the world bantamweight championship on 26 February 1968 in Tokyo .
Por Tor won in six rounds by earning more points than Rose .
Olivares knocked out Rose in the fifth round , and so Rose lost the world bantamweight title .
He then fought against world junior lightweight champion Yoshiaki Numata , on 30 May 1971 in Hiroshima .
Rose beat Castillo by decision , but the verdicts in favor of him made many in the crowd angry , as they supported Castillo .
Of his next nine fights , Rose won eight .

The number of tuberculosis cases has been decreasing since 2006 , and new cases have decreased since 2002 .
The disease usually attacks the lungs , but it can also affect other parts of the body .
Experts believe that one third of the world population is infected with M. tuberculosis .
Diagnosis of active TB relies on radiology .
About eighty percent of the population in many Asian and African countries test positive in tuberculin tests , but only five to ten percent of the United States .
There is a form of tuberculosis that is resistant to all drugs .
Doctors use a skin test , called the Mantoux test , to detect latent TB .
TB is caused by several types of mycobacteria , usually Mycobacterium tuberculosis .
In 2007 , about 13.7 million chronic cases were active globally .
It is called bacillus Calmette-Guérin vaccine .

The axial shift was caused by the redistribution of mass on the Earth 's surface , which changed the planet 's moment of inertia .
The speed of the Earth 's rotation increased , shortening the day by 1.8 microseconds due to the redistribution of Earth 's mass .
These are expected changes for an earthquake of this magnitude .
Due to the conservation of angular momentum , such changes of inertia result in small changes to the Earth 's rate of rotation .
This deviation led to a number of small planetary changes , including the length of a day and the tilt of the Earth .
Portions of Japan closest to the epicenter experienced the largest shifts .
The Pacific plate itself may have moved westwards by up to 20 m ( 66 ft ) .

It was also the fifth most powerful earthquake on Earth since modern record-keeping began in 1900 .

The biggest one was a 7.2 MW earthquake on 9 March , about 40 kilometres ( 25 mi ) from the main earthquake 's location .

At some sites such as the testis , macrophages have been shown to populate the organ through proliferation .
They also stimulate lymphocytes and other immune cells to respond to the pathogen .
Unlike short-lived neutrophils , macrophages survive longer in the body , up to several months .
Their role is to phagocytose ( engulf and then digest ) cellular debris and pathogens either as stationary or as mobile cells .
Monocytes and macrophages are phagocytes , acting in general immunity .
When a monocyte enters damaged tissue through the wall of a blood vessel it changes to become a macrophage .
Monocytes are attracted to a damaged site by chemical substances , triggered by a range of stimuli .
They also trigger specific defense mechanisms ( adaptive immunity ) of vertebrates .
Macrophages are white blood cells within tissues , produced by the differentiation of monocytes .

738.43 square miles ( 1,912.5 km2 ) ( or 97.83 % ) is land and 16.39 square miles ( 42.4 km2 ) ( or 2.17 % ) is water .
The last wild Carolina Parakeet was killed in Okeechobee County in Florida in 1904 , and the last bird kept by people died at the Cincinnati Zoo in 1918 .
It was not until 1939 , however , that it was agreed that all the Carolina parakeets had died .
It was found from the Ohio Valley to the Gulf of Mexico , and lived in old woods along rivers .
However , the American Ornithologists Union thought that they had probably recorded escaped pets .
The Carolina Parakeet died out for a number of reasons .
This was the male bird called `` Incas , '' who died within a year of his mate `` Lady Jane . ''
At some date between 1937 and 1955 , three parakeets looking like this sort of bird were seen and recorded on videotape in the Okefenokee Swamp of Georgia .
Additional sightings were recorded in Okeechobee County in Florida until the end of the 1920s .

The Smith campus covers 147 acres ( 0.6 km2 ) .

The processes for encryption and decryption are similar .
IDEA derives much of its security by interleaving operations from different groups - modular addition and multiplication , and bitwise eXclusive OR ( XOR ) - which are chosen to be `` algebraically incompatible '' .
IDEA was used in Pretty Good Privacy ( PGP ) v2 .0 after the cipher used in v1 .0 , BassOmatic , was found to be breakable .
It was meant to be a replacement for the Data Encryption Standard .
In cryptography , the International Data Encryption Algorithm ( IDEA ) is a block cipher designed by Xuejia Lai and James Massey of ETH Zurich in 1991 .
The name `` IDEA '' is also a trademark .
IDEA can be used with the OpenPGP standard .
Each of the eight round uses six sub-keys , while the half-round uses four ; for a total of 52 sub-keys .
The first eight sub-keys are extracted directly from the 128-bit key , with K1 being the lowest sixteen bits and K8 is the highest sixteen bits ; further groups of eight keys are created by rotating the main key left 25 bits after the creation of the previous group ; six rotations generate all sub-keys .
IDEA operates on 64-bit blocks , using a 128-bit key .
IDEA very like an earlier cipher called Proposed Encryption Standard ( PES ) , but with some improvements .
The cipher is patented in a number of countries but can be used by anyone for non-commercial use .
The Iron Pagoda , built in 1049 in Kaifeng , China , of glazed bricks is an example .
Glaze is also used on stoneware and porcelain .
Glaze is used on building materials .
Various metal oxides , such as sodium , potassium and calcium , act as a flux to lower the melting temperature .
Glaze can serve to color , decorate , strengthen or waterproof an item .
In addition to the functional aspect of glazes , they can form a variety of surface finishes , including degrees of gloss and matte and color .
Ceramic glaze raw materials generally include silica , which will be the main glass former .
Alumina , often derived from clay , stiffens the molten glaze to prevent it from running off the piece .
Colour comes from iron oxide , copper carbonate or cobalt carbonate .
Glazes may also enhance an underlying design or texture .
Glazing is important for earthenware vessels as otherwise they would leak water .
Tin oxide or zirconium oxide , are used to make the glaze opaque .
Pope Paul I ( Latin : Paulus Primus ; 700 - 28 June 767 ) was an Italian priest of the Roman Catholic Church and the 94th Pope from from May 29 , 757 to June 28 , 767 .
He was the brother of Pope Stephen II .
With long straights and a variety of corners , the Circuit de Catalunya is seen as an all-rounder circuit .
This has led to criticism that drivers and mechanics are too familiar with Catalunya , reducing the amount of on-track action .
Because of so much testing is done at this circuit , Formula One drivers and mechanics are extremely familiar with it .
As in Formula 1 , turn one is the most popular place for overtaking .
The Circuit de Catalunya should not be confused with the Montjuïc circuit , which hosted the Spanish Grand Prix four times between 1969 and 1975 .
The chicane which was put in for Formula 1 does not exist in the track layout for Moto GP , and there are at least five points on the track where riders are known to pass .
The Circuit de Catalunya was built in 1991 .
The Circuit de Catalunya also plays host to many other racing series , including Moto GP .

Doctor of Medicine ( MD , from the Latin Medicinæ Doctor meaning `` Teacher of Medicine '' ) is a doctoral degree for physicians ( medical doctors ) .
In other countries , such as the United Kingdom and Germany , the Doctor of Medicine is an advanced academic research degree similar to a PhD or a higher doctorate .

Henry Ian Cusick ( born April 17 , 1967 ) is an Emmy-nominated Scottish-Peruvian actor of stage , television , and movies .
This may include proof that the applicant is able to support himself in the host country ( lodging , food ) , proof that the person hosting the applicant in his or her home really exists and has sufficient room for hosting the applicant , proof that the applicant has obtained health and evacuation insurance , etc. .
The border crossing authorities make the final determination to allow entry , and may even cancel a visa at the border if the alien can not demonstrate to their satisfaction that they will abide by the status their visa grants them .
In certain circumstances , it is not possible for the holder of the visa to do this , either because the country does not have a mechanism to prolong visas or , most likely , because the holder of the visa is using a short stay visa to live in a country .
If there is no embassy or consulate in one 's home country , then one would have to travel to a third country ( or apply by post ) and try to get a visa issued there .
The need or absence of need of a visa generally depends on the citizenship of the applicant , the intended duration of the stay , and the activities that the applicant may wish to undertake in the country he visits ; these may delineate different formal categories of visas , with different issue conditions .
The issuing authority may also require applicants to attest that they have had no criminal convictions , or that they do not partake in certain activities ( like prostitution or drug trafficking ) .
A similar reciprocity often applies to the duration of the visa ( the period in which one is permitted to request entry of the country ) and the amount of entries one can attempt with the visa .
Brazil requires an advance visa before entry into the country , and that a US citizen be fingerprinted and photographed on arrival-matching U.S. requirements for Brazilians and other foreigners .
The issuing authority , usually a branch of the country 's foreign ministry or department ( e.g. U.S. State Department ) , and typically consular affairs officers , may request appropriate documentation from the applicant .
Some countries ask for proof of health status , especially for long-term visas ; some countries deny such visas to persons with certain illnesses , such as AIDS .
Countries may also issue re-entry permits that allow temporarily leaving the country without invalidating the visa .
Notable examples of countries requiring HIV tests of long-term residents are Russia and Uzbekistan .
Even a business visa will normally not allow the holder to work in the host country without an additional work permit .
For example , in Denmark a visa holder can apply to the Danish Immigration Service for a Residence Permit after they have arrived in the Country .
Staying longer than the period of authorized stay given by the immigration officers is considered illegal immigration even if the visa validity period is not over ( i.e. for multiple entry visas ) and a form of being `` out of status '' and the offender may be fined , prosecuted , deported , or even blacklisted ( banned ) from entering the country again .
Expedited processing of the visa application for some countries will generally incur additional charges .
However , in Uzbekistan , the HIV test requirement is sometimes not strictly enforced .
The fee charged may also be at the discretion of each embassy .
The exact conditions depend on the country and category of visa .
A number of countries , including Brazil , Chile , and Turkey have reciprocated .
Many countries have a mechanism to allow the holder of a visa to apply to stay longer in that country .
Once issued , a visa will usually have to be used within a certain period of time .
The validity of a visa is not the same as the authorized period of stay in the issuing country .
Common types of visas are : Less common visas include : Visas can also be single-entry , which means the visa is canceled as soon as the holder leaves the country , double-entry , or multiple-entry , permitting multiple entries into the country with the same visa .
Visas are associated with the request for permission to enter ( or exit ) a country , and are thus , for some countries , not the same as actual formal permission for an alien to enter and remain in the country .
Some countries will deny visas if the travellers ' passports show evidence of citizenship or travel to a country which is not recognized by that country .
Once in the country , the validity period of a visa or authorized stay can often be extended for a fee if the immigration authorities choose to do so .
Some countries , such as some states of the former Soviet Union , require that their citizens , and sometimes foreign travelers , obtain an exit visa in order to be allowed to leave the country .
Examples of such reciprocal visa regimes are between : A fee may be charged for issuing a visa ; these are typically also reciprocal , so if country A charges country B 's citizens 50 USD for a visa , country B will often also charge the same amount for country A 's visitors .
Such violation is not a violation of a visa , despite the common misuse of the phrase , but a violation of status , hence the term `` out of status . ''
For example , if a visa has been issued January 1st and expires March 30th , and the typical authorized period of stay in a country is 90 days , then the 90-day authorized stay starts on the day the passenger reaches the country , which has to be between January 1st and March 30th .
Entering a country without a valid visa or visa exemption may result in being arrested and removed ( deportation or exclusion ) from the country .
This reciprocal fee has become more common in recent years with the decision of the United States to charge nationals of various countries a $ 100 visa processing fee ( non-refundable , even if a visa is not issued ) .
Doing things that are not authorized by the status of entry ( for example , working while having a non-worker tourist status ) can result in the individual being deemed removable , in common speech an illegal alien .
In the United Kingdom applications can be made to the Border and Immigration Agency .
Developed countries frequently demand strong evidence of intent to return to the home country , if the visa is for a temporary stay , and especially if the applicant is from a developing country , due to immigration concerns .
For example , Saudi Arabia will not issue visas to nationals of Israel or those with evidence of visiting Israel .
Some visas can be granted on arrival or by prior application at the country 's embassy or consulate , or sometimes through a specialized travel agency with permission from the issuing country in the country of departure .
The visa validity usually indicates when the alien can apply for entry to the country .

Phylogenies have two components , branching order ( showing group relationships ) and branch length ( showing amount of evolution ) .
Phylogenetic trees of species and higher taxa are used to study the evolution of traits ( anatomical or molecular characteristics ) , and the distribution of organisms ( biogeography ) .
Systematics is used to help us understand the evolutionary history of life on Earth .
Systematics is the study of the diversification of life on the planet Earth , both past and present , and the relationships among living things through time .
Relationships are usually seen as evolutionary trees ( cladograms , phylogenetic trees , phylogenies ) .
`` Systematic biology '' and `` taxonomy '' are terms that are often confused and used interchangeably .

The Blue Tit , Cyanistes caeruleus , is a passerine songbird in the family Paridae .
The Blue Tit has an average life expectancy of 1.5 years The Blue Tit is a destroyer of pests .
It lives throughout temperate and subarctic Europe and western Asia in deciduous or mixed woodlands .

Lifeline is a non-profit organization that provides free , 24-hour telephone support to people in need .
Lifeline has more than 260 retail outlets around Australia that sell clothes and furniture to make enough money to pay for training and office space they use .
Some Lifeline Centres also provide other support services that may have group support , assistance with food & bills and support for the old people .
The 2010 report recorded 2,361 deaths by suicide in Australia , 480 more deaths than in 2007 .
A lifeline Assistance called Volunteer Crisis Supporters provides suicide prevention services ( trying to persuade people not to kill themselves ) and mental health support ( helping with depression and other issues ) .
Some Lifeline Centres have few stores which helps them with day-to-day spending .
More than 400,000 calls are served by the Lifeline Assistance every year .

Archimedes ' treatise , On floating bodies , proposition 5 states : For more general objects , floating and sunken , and in gases as well as liquids ( i.e. a fluid ) , Archimedes ' principle may be stated thus in terms of forces : For a sunken object , the volume of displaced fluid is the volume of the object , and for a floating object on a liquid , the weight of the displaced liquid is the weight of the object .

Jelckama was born in the year 1490 in a large family of farmers and petty noblemen .
After a series of defeats , he and what was left of the Frisian army were captured in 1523 and taken to the city of Leeuwarden in Frisia .
Together with Pier Gerlofs Donia , Jelckama fought against the Saxon warriors that occupied their homeland of Frisia , at the capture of Medemblik , and in the siege of Middelburg castle .
One of his ancestors from his father 's side of the family had died at the Siege of Antioch .
He was descended from knights who had participated in the Crusades .
It was the last successful revolt in Frisian history and is remembered as such to this day .
With the death of Jelckama and the rebels , the independence of Frisia came to an end .
After Donia had died in 1520 , Jelckama took over the command of the armies .

It was the primary border protection force of the then East Pakistan provincial region .

In addition , Finnix uses SquashFS to keep distribution size low .
Finnix is released as a small bootable CD ISO .
Finnix can be run completely within RAM , provided the system has at least 192 MiB RAM available .
On 23 October 2005 , Finnix 86.0 was released .
Earlier unreleased versions ( 84 , and 85.0 through 85.3 ) were `` Knoppix remasters '' , with support for Linux LVM and dm-crypt being the main reason for creation .
A user can download the ISO , burn the image to CD , and boot into a text mode Linux environment .
Any changes made during the Finnix session are transparently written to RAM and discarded upon shutdown .
However , 86.0 was a departure from Knoppix , and was derived directly from the Debian `` testing '' tree .
Most hardware devices are detected and dealt with automatically , such as hard drives , network cards and USB devices .
Finnix 0.01 was based on Red Hat Linux 6.1 , and was created to help with administration and recovery of other Linux workstations around Finnie 's office .
Finnix was created in 1999 , making it one of the oldest Linux distributions with the intent of being run completely from a bootable CD ( the other Live CD around at the time was the Linuxcare Bootable Business Card CD , first released in 1999 ) .
Finnix is a Debian based Live CD Linux distribution , developed by Ryan Finnie and intended for system administrators for tasks such as filesystem recovery , network monitoring and OS installation .
A user can modify files nearly anywhere on the running CD via UnionFS , a filesystem that can stack a read-write filesystem ( in this case , a dynamic ramdisk ) on top of a read-only filesystem ( the CD media ) .
Finnix requires at least 32MiB RAM to run properly , but can use more if present .
Finnix is a small Linux Distribution , with an ISO download size of approximately 100 MiB .
Common spacing is one plant per square for larger plants such as broccoli and basil , four per square for medium large plants like lettuce , nine per square for medium - small plants like spinach , and sixteen per square for small plants such as onions and carrots .

Pink Floyd had moderate mainstream success and were one of the most popular bands in the London underground music scene in the late 1960s led by Syd Barrett ; however , Barrett 's decline in health would eventually forced his band members to replace him with guitarist and singer David Gilmour .
The band recorded several albums , achieving worldwide success with The Dark Side of the Moon ( 1973 ) , Wish You Were Here ( 1975 ) , Animals ( 1977 ) , and The Wall ( 1979 ) with all of them topping the American record chart with the exception of Animals .
Waters sued the remaining members for the rights to the name , Waters lost and the band enjoyed worldwide success with A Momentary Lapse of Reason ( 1987 ) and The Division Bell ( 1994 ) .
One of rock music 's most successful acts , the group have sold over 210 million albums worldwide , including 74.5 million albums in the United States alone .
In 1985 , Waters stated that Pink Floyd was no more , but the remaining members , led by Gilmour , continued recording and touring under the name Pink Floyd .
The album was released as a double disc , the first disc contained songs performed live the other disc contained the new studio recorded songs .
Pink Floyd has released twelve studio albums , four live albums , seven compilations , five soundtracks , thirty-five singles , eleven music videos , four video albums and three box sets .
Formed in 1964 , Pink Floyd was first known for their psychedelic or space rock music and in later years their progressive rock music .
Singer and bass player Roger Waters gradually became the leader of the band in the mid-1970s , until 1985 when he left the group .
After Barrett left the group Pink Floyd released Ummagumma .
The Dark Side of the Moon is the third best-selling studio album in the world ( not counting compilations and various artists soundtracks ) .

A derny race is a race in which the cyclists are paced by someone riding a derny .

The Scottish Premier League ( currently known as the Clydesdale Bank Premier League or SPL ) was a professional competition for football clubs .
The increase from 10 clubs to 12 was part of the deal offered to get approval from SPL member clubs .
Former Rangers manager Alex McLeish accused the SPL of taking Scottish football `` back to the Dark Ages '' after its decision to stop the winter break , meaning that they were going back to an old , outdated system .
Three points are awarded for a win and one point for a draw .
Eighteen clubs have played in the SPL since it began in 1998 , but only two have won the title : the Old Firm of Celtic and Rangers both seven times .
If two or more teams are equal on points , then the difference between of goals scored and goals against is considered .
Former Celtic manager Martin O'Neill , former Dundee manager Jim Duffy , and former Rangers manager Walter Smith are among those who have asked to start the winter break again .
The season runs from August until May each year .
Each club will then play five more games against clubs in their half of the table .

The average distance from Kepler-22b to its host star Kepler-22 is about 15 % less than the distance from Earth to the Sun but the luminosity ( light output ) of Kepler-22 is about 25 % less than that of the Sun .
If the orbit is indeed highly elliptical , then the temperature variance range will be extreme .
If the planet is found to move in a highly elliptical orbit , its surface temperature will vary from a higher temperature when close to Kepler-22 to lower when further away .
This combination of a shorter average distance from the star and a lower stellar luminosity are consistent with a moderate surface temperature at that distance if we assume that the surface is not subject to extreme greenhouse heating .
On December 5 , 2011 , the confirmation of the existence of Kepler-22b was announced .
Kepler-22b 's first transit in front of its host sun was observed on Kepler 's third day of scientific operations in mid-2009 .
It is also the first known planet to orbit within the habitable zone of a Sun-like star .
It is located about 600 light years away from Earth in the constellation Cygnus .
Kepler-22b is an extrasolar planet orbiting ( going around ) G-type star Kepler-22 .
Kepler-22b 's third transit was detected in late 2010 .
Scientists can estimate the possible surface conditions as follows :
The Spitzer Space Telescope provided more data that confirmed Kepler-22b 's transits .
Crater Lake has no streams flowing into or out of it .
Crater Lake National Park is a national park in the U.S. state of Oregon .
It is the deepest lake in the United States , the second deepest in North America and the ninth deepest in the world .
All water that enters the lake is eventually lost from evaporation or flowing away underground .
The park includes the caldera of Crater Lake , the remains of the destroyed volcano Mount Mazama , and nearby hills and forests .
It is the only national park in Oregon .
The lake is re-filled only from snow and rain .

In April 2008 , Richard Sundance Owen , a building contractor and scuba dive instructor , started the Environmental Cleanup Coalition to solve the problem of the pollution in the North Pacific .
In August 2009 two ships from the project , the RV New Horizon and the Kaisei , went to research the patch and decide the possibility of a commercial scale collection and recycling operation .
The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is a big patch of garbage and debris in the middle of the northern Pacific Ocean .
The basic message was that the states were the ultimate parties constituting the federal compact , and that therefore the individual states were ultimate arbiters of whether the compact had been broken by the usurpation of power .
Particularly at issue was the sense in which the states were parties to the federal compact .
To remedy the defects revealed by the passage of the Alien and Sedition Acts , Madison called for citizens to have an absolute right to free speech .
Jefferson , the leader of the Republican Party and then-Vice President , wrote to Madison in August 1799 outlining a campaign to strengthen public support for the principles expressed in the Virginia and Kentucky Resolutions of 1798 ( commonly referred to as `` the principles of ' 98 '' ) : In response to this letter , Madison visited Jefferson at Monticello during the first week of September .
Either formulation would help the Republican cause by refuting the finality of any constitutional interpretation advanced by the Congress and federal judiciary , both of which were dominated by Federalists .
H. Jefferson Powell , a modern jurist , identifies three persistent themes of Republican constitutionalism which emerged from the Resolutions and the Report : ( 1 ) a textual approach to the Constitution , ( 2 ) the compact theory , and ( 3 ) that caution , not trust , should characterize our approach to those who hold political power .
More generally , the Report made the argument in favor of the sovereignty of the individual states , for which it is best known .
The Report of 1800 , Madison argued , did not say the government was a compact of the individual states , as the pro-nullification elements suggested .
The first major goal of the Resolutions was to bring about the repeal of the Alien and Sedition Acts by generating public opposition that would be expressed through the state legislatures .
Whether Madison 's theory of republicanism really supported the nullification movement , and more broadly whether the ideas he expressed between 1798 and 1800 are consistent with his work before and after this period , are the main questions surrounding the Report in the modern literature .
The most significant of these were the Alien and Sedition Acts , four laws that allowed the President to deport aliens at will , required a longer period of residence before aliens could become citizens , and made it a crime to publish malicious or defamatory material against the government or its officials .
Jefferson eagerly sought copies for distribution to Republican members of Congress departing for their home states , and when they failed to arrive he entreated Monroe for at least one copy that he could reproduce .
Once at Richmond , Madison began drafting the Report , though he was delayed by a weeklong battle with dysentery .
The arguments made in the Resolutions and the Report were later used frequently during the nullification crisis of 1832 , when South Carolina declared federal tariffs to be unconstitutional and void within the state .
The reason for the criticism was that the General Assembly , led in the effort by state-sovereignty advocate John Taylor of Caroline , had put a state-sovereignty spin on the Virginia Resolutions of 1798 despite Madison 's hopes .
Spencer Roane described it as `` the Magna Charta on which the republicans settled down , after the great struggle in the year 1799 . ''
Their discussion was important in that it persuaded Jefferson to depart from his radical stance on dissociation from the Union , which is expressed at the end of the excerpt above .
Madison won over Jefferson , who shortly thereafter wrote to Wilson Cary Nicholas that : `` From ( this position ) I retreat readily , not only in deference to ( Madison 's ) judgment but because as we should never think of separation but for repeated and enormous violations , so these , when they occur , will be cause enough of themselves . ''
In defense of Virginia Republicans and the Resolutions , Madison emphasized that even if one disagreed with the compact theory , the Virginia Resolutions and the Report of 1800 themselves were simply protests , which states were surely entitled to produce .
On December 23 , Madison moved for the creation of a special seven-member committee with himself as chairman to respond to `` certain answers from several of the states , relative to the communications made by the Virginia legislature at their last session . ''
The General Assembly arranged for five thousand copies to be printed and distributed in the state , but there was not much public response to the Report , and it appears to have had relatively little impact on the presidential election of 1800 ( which was , nevertheless , a major victory for the Republicans and a repudiation of Federalist policies ) .
Madison thought the Resolutions and Report were consistent with this principle while the Ordinance of Nullification was not .
Rather the Report of 1800 described a compact of `` the people in each of the States , acting in their highest sovereign capacity . ''
According to Kevin Gutzman , the Report , together with the Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions , forms a foundation for the `` radical southern states ' rights tradition . ''
Madison writes that the ability to prosecute speech amounts to `` a protection of those who administer the government , if they should at any time deserve the contempt or hatred of the people , against being exposed to it . ''
Adrienne Koch and Harry Ammon , examining Jefferson 's later writing , conclude that Madison had a significant role `` in softening Jefferson 's more extreme views . ''
While the Federalists interpreted the amendment as limiting the power of Congress over the press , but implying that such power existed , Madison argued that the First Amendment wholly prohibited Congress from any interference with the press .
The task of writing the Virginia Report was left solely to Madison .
Jefferson hoped for further involvement with the production of the Report and planned to visit Madison at Montpelier on his way to Philadelphia , the national capital , for the winter session of the United States Congress .
The main point of contention was the meaning of the third of the Virginia Resolutions : This resolution had been the principal target of the Federalist attack on the Resolutions .
The Alien Act granted the President the unenumerated power of deporting friendly aliens .
As well , Madison attacked Federalist carriage laws and bank laws as unconstitutional .
Though certain to pass due to the Republican majority , which had recently been solidified by the election of a Republican clerk and speaker of the House , the Report was debated for five days .
It was the presence of this argument in the Resolutions that had allowed the Federalists to paint the Republicans as leaning toward secession ; in the amended Report the line is moderated , with an emphasis that it is the states as political societies of the people ( and therefore , one reads in , not the state legislatures alone ) which possess this power .
This doctrine is known as the compact theory .
The state governments themselves , no less than the federal judiciary , possess only delegated power and therefore can not decide questions of fundamental importance .
The next day , Christmas Eve , the committee produced a first version of the Report .
Though it had little impact on the immediate election , Madison 's Report clarified the legal argument against the Acts and for states ' rights in general , particularly in its advancement of the Tenth Amendment rather than the Ninth as the main bulwark against federal encroachment on state autonomy .
Madison , a member of the Republican Party , was elected to the Republican-dominated Virginia General Assembly from Orange County in 1799 .
The Resolutions , usually discussed together with Thomas Jefferson 's contemporaneous Kentucky Resolutions , were a response to various perceived outrages perpetrated by the Federalist-dominated national government .
A major item on his agenda was the defense of the General Assembly 's 1798 Virginia Resolutions , of which Madison had been the draftsman .
However , James Monroe , who would become Governor of Virginia before the end of the year , visited Jefferson at Monticello and cautioned him against meeting with Madison , since another meeting between two of the most important Republican leaders would provoke significant public comment .
The committee members were Madison , John Taylor , William Branch Giles , George Keith Taylor , John Wise , John Mercer , and William Daniel .
These replies contended that the Supreme Court of the United States had the ultimate responsibility for deciding whether federal laws were constitutional , and that the Alien and Sedition Acts were constitutional and necessary .
The amended Report passed the House of Delegates on January 7 by a margin of 60 to 40 .
In the 1957 Roth v. United States opinion by William Brennan , Madison 's Report is cited as evidence that `` the fundamental freedoms of speech and press have contributed greatly to the development and well-being of our free society and are indispensable to its continued growth . ''
Madison sought to accomplish this by demonstrating conclusively that the Acts violated the constitution .
Henry Clay said on the floor of the House of Representatives that it was from the Report of 1800 , above other documents , that he had developed his own theories on constitutional interpretation .
Laying into the Acts in his Report , Madison described many breaches of constitutional limits .
The Federalists accused the Republicans of seeking disunion , even contemplating violence .
The Report was received warmly by Virginia Republicans .
In modern scholarship outside the legal arena the Report is mostly studied for its discussion of states ' rights with regard to federalism and republicanism .
Multiple Supreme Court decisions have cited the case as evidence of the Framers ' ideas on free speech .
The Report supported a strict interpretation of the First Amendment .
By eschewing direct action in favor of influencing popular opinion , Madison tried to make clear that the Republicans were not moving toward disunion .
The measure came before the House of Delegates , the lower house of the General Assembly , on January 2 .
Jefferson underlined the importance of this work in a November 26 letter to Madison in which he identified `` protestations against violations of the true principles of our constitution '' as one of the four primary elements of the Republican Party plan .
The Assembly session began in early December .
Contrary to the Sedition Act , the federal government had no power to protect officials from dissent or libelous attack , beyond the protection it accorded to every citizen ; indeed , such special intervention against the press was `` expressly forbidden by a declaratory amendment to the constitution . ''
Republicans were outraged by the legislation , and Madison and Jefferson drafted the highly critical Resolutions adopted in response by the Virginia and Kentucky state legislatures .
At some point in the next two weeks , it passed the Senate by a margin of 15 to 6 .
In more recent years , the main practical interest in the Report has been its absolutist understanding of the First Amendment .
Other cases to cite the Report for a similar purpose include Thornhill v. Alabama ( 1940 ) and Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC ( 2000 ) .
At the very least , Virginia or Kentucky taking such a stance publicly would have justified the Federalist attacks against the secessionist tendencies of the Republicans .
However , Madison rebuffed charges that his writings supported the constitutional interpretation advanced by pro-nullification Southerners .
Freedom of the press was necessary , because `` chequered as it is with abuses , the world is indebted to the press for all the triumphs which have been gained by reason and humanity over error and oppression . ''
The Report was regarded in the early 19th century as among the more important expressions of Republican principles .
Parties outside Virginia seemed uninterested in the rehashing of the 1798 Resolutions , and in other states there was very little public comment .
At the time , leading Virginia Republican figures such as Rep. William Branch Giles ( in public ) and Sen. John Taylor of Caroline ( in private ) actually were contemplating disunion , and the Virginia General Assembly chose this juncture for finally constructing a new state armory in Richmond , so there was some truth to the charge .
Despite Jefferson 's approval of and attempt to distribute Madison 's work , the national reaction was tepid .
The general purpose of the Report was the affirmation and expansion of the principles in the Virginia Resolutions .
It argued for the sovereignty of the individual states under the United States Constitution and against the Alien and Sedition Acts .
Madison , however , rejected the concept of nullification and the notion that his arguments supported such a practice .
The Report was the last important explication of the Constitution produced before the 1817 Bonus Bill Veto Message .
The Virginia Resolutions had in the year since publication received highly critical replies from state legislatures , including those of New York , Delaware , and the five New England states .
The Report was ultimately amended to provide greater clarity on this issue by emphasizing that it was the people themselves , acting through the states in their sovereign capacity , who were parties to the Constitution .
The Virginia General Assembly adopted the Report in January 1800 .

The history of Elam is conventionally divided into three periods , spanning more than two millennia .

Elam was centered in the far west and the southwest of modern-day Iran , including a small part of southern Iraq .

The main garment of an ice hockey uniform , which was traditionally called a sweater , is increasingly known as a hockey jersey .
Jersey , in the Channel Islands , was famous for its knitting trade in medieval times , and because of that original fame , the name jersey is still applied to many forms of knitted fabric , round or flat .
Many Cycling jerseys of specific color or pattern represent certain statuses in cycling , such as the maillot jaune ( yellow jersey ) of the leader of the Tour de France , or the rainbow jersey .
It is usually close-fitting and machine knitted in contrast to a guernsey that is more often hand knit with a thicker yarn .
The traditional jersey , and traditional guernsey , are dyed a navy blue color , using a dye that does not require stripping the wool of its natural oil , rendering these sweaters surprisingly water resistant .
The wool used in guernseys is often passed through oil in order to render it doubly water-resistant .
When a jersey is retired that player 's jersey is placed usually where the team plays in honor of that player 's accomplishment .
In some sports , such as baseball , basketball , and American football , a player 's jersey may be `` retired '' .
This garment , along with basketball jerseys which are usually sleeveless and baseball jerseys which are usually button up , have become fashion accessories .
Its name comes from the island of Jersey , where they were made , traditionally in wool or cotton , with sleeves , worn as a sweater or pullover , as it does not open at the front , unlike a cardigan .
In sport a jersey is a shirt worn by a member of a team , often with the wearer 's name and team number as well .
The word is usually used interchangeably with sweater and is the name always officially used in the United Kingdom to refer to the item when worn as part of the uniform of military , police or other uniformed personnel .
Cycling jerseys are usually made of special synthetic material to help sweat away from the skin .
The retiring of a jersey at one time included the retiring of the number on the player 's jersey leaving it unavailable for future players , to further honor that player .
Werner Karl Heisenberg ( 5 December 1901 - 1 February 1976 ) was a German physicist .
He won the Nobel Prize in Physics for his work in quantum mechanics .
After the war , he was held as a prisoner at Farm Hall in England from May 1945 to January , 1946 , where the British and Americans had many other German scientists .
He was awarded the Nobel Prize when he was 31 years old .

In recent years , successful efforts have been made to remove possums , rats , ferrets , and other mammals from many offshore islands , large and small .
Because of this , the country has an unusually large number of flightless birds , including the Kiwi , the Moa , and the Kakapo .
They brought with them the Polynesian Rat ( Kiore ) and the domesticated dog .
Possums were later introduced from Australia for a fur industry , and deer from Europe as animals to be hunted .
Of these , the rats , ferrets , cats , stoats and dogs have all had serious effect on the original New Zealand animals .
In some parts of the mainland , mammals are being completely eliminated inside fenced areas to create `` ecological islands '' .
People are also trying to control these species on the mainland .
The Aidi or Chien de l'Atlas is a Moroccan dog breed used to protect flocks of sheep and goats .
In its native Morocco it is often paired in hunting with the Sloughi , which chases down prey that the Aidi has located by sniffing it out .
It was named in August 2003 after Orthosie , the Greek goddess of prosperity and one of the Horae .
The Horae ( Hours ) were daughters of Zeus and Themis .
It was found by a team of astronomers from the University of Hawaii led by Scott Sheppard in 2001 , and given the designation S\/2001 J 9 .
Orthosie is about 2 kilometres in diameter , and orbits Jupiter at an average distance of 20,568,000 km in 602.619 days , at an inclination of 142 ° to the ecliptic ( 143 ° to Jupiter 's equator ) , with an orbital eccentricity of 0.2433 .
Orthosie belongs to the Ananke group , retrograde non-spherical moons which orbit Jupiter between 19,300,000 and 22,700,000 km , at inclinations of about 150 ° .

The Daily Pennsylvanian ( The DP ) is the independent daily student newspaper of the University of Pennsylvania .
It was also ranked as the `` most read '' college newspaper by The Princeton Review in 1990 , 1997 , 1998 , and 2001 .
It also won the award in 1990 , 1997 , and 1998 , and most recently in 2007 .
Today the newspaper 's budget is funded primarily through the sale of advertising by a student business staff .
Founded in 1885 , the newspaper has been published daily since 1894 , except for a hiatus from May 1943 to November 1945 on account of World War II .

The Weather Makers : The History and Future Impact of Climate Change ( 2005 ) is a book by Tim Flannery .
The book asserts that if atmospheric carbon dioxide levels continue to increase at current rates , the resulting climate change will cause mass species extinctions .
The book received much critical acclaim , and has won a major literary prize .
The book reviews the evidence about historical climate change and attempts to put our era into context .

He sought to consolidate royal power and crush domestic factions .
The Cardinal de Richelieu was often known by the title of the King 's `` Chief Minister '' .
Richelieu is also known by the sobriquet l'Éminence rouge ( `` the Red Eminence '' ) , from the red shade of a cardinal 's vestments and the style `` eminence '' as a cardinal .
Richelieu was also famous for his patronage of the arts ; most notably , he founded the Académie française , the learned society responsible for matters of the French language .
As an advocate for Samuel de Champlain and of the keeping of Quebec , he founded the Compagnie des Cent-Associés and saw the Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye return Quebec to French rule under de Champlain , after the settlement had been captured by the Kirkes in 1629 .
By restraining the power of the nobility , he transformed France into a strongly centralized state .
This in part allowed the colony to eventually develop into the heartland of French-speaking culture in North America .
He became King Louis XIII 's chief minister in 1624 .
His full name was Armand Jean du Plessis , cardinal-duc de Richelieu et de Fronsac .
He remained in office until his death in 1642 ; then Jules Cardinal Mazarin became chief minister .
His chief foreign policy objective was to check the power of the Austro-Spanish Habsburg dynasty ; although a Roman Catholic cardinal , he did not hesitate to make alliances with Protestant rulers .
As a result , he is sometimes said to be the world 's first Prime Minister .
He later entered politics and became a Secretary of State in 1616 .
Willesden is an area found in North-west London .
The April 2011 derecho and tornado outbreak was a large scale event where tornadoes and derechoes , or widespread straight-line winds , damaged parts of 3 states resulting in 9 fatalities .
Tornadoes were als possible .
The yellow-lipped sea krait ( Laticauda Colubrina ) is a species of sea snake found in tropical Indo-Pacific ocean waters .
The upper lip and snout is yellow ( hence its name ) while the rest of the head is black .

Immediately after winning the match , Alekhine announced that he was willing to give Capablanca a return match , on the same terms that Capablanca had required as champion - the challenger must provide a stake of US $ 10,000 , of which more than half would go to the defending champion even if he was defeated .
At the beginning of the tournament , Ossip Bernstein and Aron Nimzowitsch objected to Capablanca 's presence because he had not fulfilled the entry condition of winning at least third prize in two master tournaments .
At the age of eight he was taken to Havana Chess Club , which had hosted many important contests , but on the advice of a doctor he was not allowed to play frequently .
In December 1921 , shortly after becoming World Champion , Capablanca married Gloria Simoni Betancourt .
Capablanca entered the match with no technical or physical preparation , while Alekhine got himself into good physical condition , and had thoroughly studied Capablanca 's play .
Vladimir Kramnik thought that Lasker played quite well and the match was an `` even and fascinating fight '' until Lasker blundered in the last game .
In the same year he joined the Manhattan Chess Club , and was soon recognized as the club 's strongest player .
Between November and December 1901 , he narrowly beat the Cuban Chess Champion , Juan Corzo , in a match .
A group of Argentinian businessmen , backed by a guarantee from the president of Argentina , promised the funds for a World Championship match between Capablanca and Alekhine in 1927 .
The match was played in March-April 1921 ; Lasker resigned it after just fourteen games , having lost four games and won none .
His loss , against Rubinstein , was one of the most brilliant achievements of the latter 's career .
Vladimir Kramnik commented that this was the first contest in which Capablanca had no easy wins .
In 1908 he left the university to concentrate on chess .
He was particularly dominant in rapid chess , winning a tournament ahead of the reigning World Chess Champion , Emanuel Lasker , in 1906 .
According to Capablanca , he learned the rules of the game at the age of four by watching his father play , pointed out an illegal move by his father , and then beat his father twice .
Their relationship became bitter , and Alekhine demanded much higher appearance fees for tournaments in which Capablanca also played .
Capablanca was now recognized as a serious contender for the world championship .
According to Kasparov , Alekhine 's research uncovered many small inaccuracies , which occurred because Capablanca was unwilling to concentrate intensely .
Capablanca 's high blood pressure was not correctly diagnosed and treated until after the AVRO tournament , and caused him to lose his train of thought towards the end of playing sessions .
Capablanca placed first in the preliminary tournament , 1 1\/2 points ahead of Lasker , who was out of practice and made a shaky start .
Lasker accepted his challenge while proposing seventeen conditions for the match .
Despite a determined effort by Lasker , Capablanca still seemed on course for ultimate victory .
Capablanca objected to some of the conditions , which significantly favored Lasker , and the match did not take place .
In January 1920 , Emanuel Lasker and Capablanca signed an agreement to play a World Championship match in 1921 .
After the breakdown of his attempt to negotiate a title match in 1911 , Capablanca drafted rules for the conduct of future challenges , which were agreed by the other top players at the 1914 Saint Petersburg tournament , including Lasker , and approved at the Mannheim Congress later that year .
However , in April 1902 he only came fourth out of six in the National Championship , losing both his games against Corzo .
Luděk Pachman suggested that Capablanca , who was unused to losing games or to any other type of setback , became depressed over his unnecessary loss of the eleventh game , a long , gruelling endgame , featuring errors by both players .
However , in their second game of the final , Lasker reduced Capablanca to a helpless position and Capablanca was so shaken by this that he blundered away his next game to Tarrasch .
The St. Petersburg event was arranged in an unusual way : after a preliminary single-round all-play-all tournament of eleven players , the top five were to play a second stage in a double round format , with scores from the preliminary tournament carried forward to the second contest .
The following year , Capablanca won an even stronger tournament in Moscow , one point ahead of Botvinnik and 3 1\/2 ahead of Salo Flohr , who took third place ; A month later , he shared first place with Botvinnik at Nottingham , with a mark of ( +5 -1 = 8 ) , losing only to Flohr ; Alekhine came sixth .
José Raúl Capablanca y Graupera ( Havana , Cuba , 19 November 1888 - New York , 8 March 1942 ) was a Cuban chess player who was World Chess Champion from 1921 to 1927 .
Alekhine 's victory surprised almost the entire chess world .
Since Capablanca had won the New York 1927 tournament overwhelmingly , and had never lost a game to Alekhine , he was regarded by most pundits as the clear favorite in their 1927 World Chess Championship match .
The main points were : the champion must be prepared to defend his title once a year ; the match should be won by the first player to win six or eight games , whichever the champion preferred ; and the stake should be at least # 1,000 ( worth about # 347,000 or $ 700,000 in 2006 terms ) .
and could only finish seventh of the eight players at the 1938 AVRO tournament , an élite contest designed to select a challenger for Alekhine 's world title .
p33 In 1911 , Capablanca challenged Emanuel Lasker for the World Chess Championship .
Negotiations for a return match dragged on for several years , often breaking down when agreement seemed in sight .
After Capablanca 's death , Alekhine expressed surprise at his own victory , since in 1927 he had not thought he was superior to Capablanca , and he suggested that Capablanca had been over-confident .
Kramnik 's explanation was that Capablanca was twenty years younger , a slightly stronger player , and had more recent competitive practice .
However , Alekhine won the match , played at Buenos Aires , by 6 wins , 3 losses , and 25 draws - the longest World Championship match until the World Chess Championship 1984-85 between Anatoly Karpov and Garry Kasparov .
He made another bad start at the Moscow 1925 chess tournament , and could only fight back to third place , two points behind Bogolyubov and 1\/2 point behind Emanuel Lasker .
According to Capablanca 's second wife , Olga , his first marriage broke down fairly soon .
`` He had no specific duties , but was expected to act as a kind of ambassador-at-large , a well-known figure who would put Cuba on the map wherever he traveled '' .

p67 In September 1913 , Capablanca secured a job in the Cuban Foreign Office , which made him financially secure throughout his life .
He astounded the chess world by taking first place , with a score of six wins , one loss and seven draws , ahead of Akiba Rubinstein , Milan Vidmar , Frank Marshall , Carl Schlechter and Siegbert Tarrasch .

These 1936 tournaments , the last of Lasker 's life , were the only ones in which Capablanca finished ahead of Lasker .
Lasker thus finished half a point ahead of Capablanca and 3 1\/2 ahead of Alekhine .

Capablanca finished fourth , one point behind the joint winners at Moscow in 1935 ; Emanuel Lasker 's third place at the age of 66 was widely admired .

A heating radiator works just like a cooling radiator .

As of the census of 2010 , there were 18,367 people , 8,296 households , and 4,626 families residing in the city .
According to the United States Census Bureau , the city has a total area of 14.67 square miles ( 38.00 km2 ) , of which , 13.82 square miles ( 35.79 km2 ) is land and 0.85 square miles ( 2.20 km2 ) is water .
The American Indians called the area `` Ahdawagam '' , meaning `` Two-sided Rapids '' .
38.7 % of all households were made up of individuals and 16.8 % had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older .
The median age in the city was 41.1 years .
22.8 % of residents were under the age of 18 ; 8.5 % were between the ages of 18 and 24 ; 23.3 % were from 25 to 44 ; 25.5 % were from 45 to 64 ; and 19.8 % were 65 years of age or older .
Although this is a list of radio stations based in the Wisconsin Rapids area , the signals of radio stations from much of Central Wisconsin are commonly received in the city .
There were 8,972 housing units at an average density of 649.2 per square mile ( 250.7 \/ km2 ) .
Although Europeans began to settle this area in the 1830s , Wisconsin Rapids has been known by this name only since 1920 .
There were 8,296 households out of which 27.1 % had children under the age of 18 living with them , 39.1 % were married couples living together , 11.9 % had a female householder with no husband present , 4.8 % had a male householder with no wife present , and 44.2 % were non-families .
The population density was 1,329.0 inhabitants per square mile ( 513.1 \/ km2 ) .

Starting from version 10.0 , Mandrake Linux became known as Mandrakelinux , and its logo changed accordingly .
The development tree of Mandriva Linux has always been known as Cooker .
In February 2004 , MandrakeSoft lost a court case against Hearst Corporation , owners of King Features Syndicate .
As a precaution , MandrakeSoft renamed its products by removing the space between the brand name and the product name and changing the first letter of the product name to lower case , thus creating one word .
This tree is directly released as a new stable version .
Hearst claimed that MandrakeSoft infringed upon King Features ' trademarked character Mandrake the Magician .
From its first release to version 8.0 , Mandrake named its flagship distribution Linux-Mandrake .
From version 8.1 to 9.2 it was called Mandrake Linux .
Its first release was based on Red Hat Linux 5.1 and was released in July 1998 .
Similarly , MandrakeMove became Mandrakemove .
Mandriva Linux was originated by Gaël Duval , and intended to focus on ease of use for new users .
The latest stable version is Mandriva Linux 2009 ( 2009.0 ) , released on 2008-10-09 .
Quena is mostly used in traditional Andean music .
The quena is also relatively common in World music .
In the 1980s and 1990s some post-Nueva Canción rock groups have also used the quena in some of their songs ; notably Soda Stereo in Cuando Pase el Temblor and Los Enanitos Verdes in Lamento Boliviano .
In most of Andes ' towns `` vamos a ir a la quena '' ( we will go to the quena ) was used to threaten little children , because the quena was made of bamboo , a hard material .
To make a sound , the player closes the top end of the pipe with the flesh between his chin and lower lip , and blows a stream of air downward , over a notch cut into the end .
The quenacho ( also `` kenacho '' in English ) is a bigger , lower sounding type of quena and made the same way .
In the 1960s and 1970s the quena was used by several Nueva Canción musicians .
Made of bamboo , it has six finger holes and one thumb hole and is open on both ends .
It is in the key of D major , a fourth lower than the quena .
It is normally in the key of G major .

The duke of Saxe-Hildburghausen gave up his duchy in return for becoming Duke of Saxe-Altenburg .

Most massive stars have luminosities far below the Eddington luminosity , so their winds are mostly driven by the less intense line absorption .
The Eddington limit explains the observed luminosity of accreting black holes such as quasars .
The state of balance is a hydrostatic equilibrium .
When a star exceeds the Eddington limit , it loses mass with a very intense radiation-driven stellar wind from its outer layers .
The Eddington limit , or Eddington luminosity was first worked out by Arthur Eddington .
The Kansas Turnpike is owned and repaired by the Kansas Turnpike Authority ( KTA ) , which is based in Wichita .

Parts of the turnpike also are parts of four Interstate Highways : I-35 , I-335 , I-470 , and I-70 .
The Kansas Turnpike was built between 1954 and 1956 .

It runs through many important cities in Kansas , including Wichita , Topeka , Lawrence , and Kansas City .

It was built before the Interstate Highway System .
Around 120,000 people use the Kansas Turnpike every day .

Before this , the popular idea of dinosaurs had been one of plodding , reptilian giants .
As in other dromaeosaurids , the tail vertebrae have a series of ossified ( bony ) tendons and super-long bone processes .
The species name antirrhopus means `` counter balance '' , which refers to Ostrom 's idea about the function of the tail .
Teeth discovered associated with Tenontosaurus specimens imply it was hunted or at least scavenged upon by Deinonychus .
A fossil of the very closely related Velociraptor mongoliensis has an articulated tail skeleton that is curved laterally in a long S-shape .
Ostrom noted the small body , sleek , horizontal , posture , and-especially-the enlarged claws on the feet , which suggested an active , agile predator .
Deinonychus remains have been found closely associated with those of the ornithopod Tenontosaurus .
Paleontologist John Ostrom 's study of Deinonychus in the late 1960s started the debate on whether dinosaurs were warm-blooded .
Deinonychus has been described as the single most important discovery of dinosaur paleontology in the mid 20th century .
This suggests that , in life , the tail could swish to the sides with some flexibility .

The current position of the English Channel was a large river flowing westwards and fed by tributaries that would later become the Thames and Seine .
Food animal populations seem to have declined although woodland coverage expanded .
Many more open air sites are known such as that at Hengistbury Head .
Tool manufacture in the Final Upper Palaeolithic revolved around smaller flints and bone and antler work became less common .
The dominant food species were the Wild Horse ( Equus ferus ) and Red Deer ( Cervus elaphus ) although other mammals ranging from hares to mammoth were also hunted .
The environment during this ice age period would have been a largely treeless tundra , eventually replaced by a warmer climate , perhaps reaching 17 degrees Celsius ( 62.6 Fahrenheit ) in summer which encouraged the expansion of birch trees as well as shrub and grasses .
The first written record of Britain and its inhabitants was by the Greek navigator Pytheas , who explored the coastal region of Britain around 325 BC .
At this time , southern and eastern Britain was linked to continental Europe by a wide land bridge allowing humans to move freely .
Farming of both crops and domestic animals was adopted in Britain around 4,500 BC at least partly because of the need for reliable food sources .
There is evidence from bones and flint tools found in coastal deposits near Happisburgh in Norfolk and Pakefield in Suffolk that Homo erectus was present in what is now Britain around 700,000 years ago .
However , the number of known sites is much larger and more widely spread .
This huge length of time saw many changes in the environment , several glacial and interglacial periods which greatly affected human settlement in the region .
Ancient Britons were however involved in extensive trade and cultural links with the rest of Europe from the Neolithic onwards , especially in exporting tin .
A final ice age covered Britain between around 70,000 and 10,000 years ago with an extreme cold snap between 22,000 and 13,000 years ago which may have driven humans south out of Britain altogether .
The most famous example from this period is the burial of the Red Lady of Paviland in modern day Wales .
There is little evidence of human occupation during the subsequent Ipswichian interglacial between around 130,000 and 110,000 years ago .
None of the pre-Roman inhabitants of Britain had any written language , so their history , culture and way of life are known only through archaeological finds .
The more advanced flint technology permitted more efficient hunting .
The extreme cold of the following Anglian glaciation is likely to have driven humans out of Britain altogether .
Neanderthal occupation of Britain was limited and by 30,000 BC the first signs of modern human ( Homo sapiens ) activity .
By 10,500 years ago the climate was becoming cooler and dryer .

South Asia ( or Southern Asia ) is the south area of Asia .

Ambulocetus did not have external ears .
In addition , its teeth are similar to those of early cetaceans .
Ambulocetids may have hunted like crocodiles , lurking in the shallows to snatch unsuspecting prey .
To detect prey on land , they may have lowered their heads to the ground and felt for vibrations .
Chemical analysis of its teeth shows that it was able to move between salt and fresh water .
It had an adaptation in the nose that enabled it to swallow underwater , and its periotic bones had a structure like those of whales , enabling it to hear well underwater .
Ambulocetus natans lived from the early Eocene ( 50 to 48 million years ago ) .
When the animal was alive , Pakistan was a coastal region of India , which was then a large island in the Indian Ocean .
It was clearly amphibious : its back legs are better adapted for swimming than for walking on land , and it probably swam by undulating its back vertically , as otters and whales do .

If necessary , forecasters may make adjustments to the computer forecasts .
One of the British stalwarts , the Shipping Forecast , is produced by the Met Office and broadcast on BBC Radio 4 .
The Met Office is responsible for issuing Severe Weather Warnings for the United Kingdom through the National Severe Weather Warning Service ( NSWWS ) .
In March 2008 , the system was improved and a new stage of warning was introduced , the ` Advisory ' .
The principal weather products for UK customers are 36-hour forecasts from the newly operational 1.5 km resolution UKV model covering the UK and surroundings ( replacing the 4 km model ) ; 48-hour forecasts from the 12 km resolution NAE model covering Europe and the North Atlantic ; and 144-hour forecasts from the 25 km resolution global model ( replacing the 40 km global model ) .
The Met Office ( now the official name for the Meteorological Office ) is the United Kingdom 's national weather service .
A wide range of other products for other regions of the globe are sold to customers abroad .
Part of the Met Office headquarters at Exeter in Devon is the Met Office College .
It gathers information from weather satellites in space and observations on earth .
The Shipping Forecast has long been vital to the safety of mariners on the seas around the British Isles .
These warn of weather which may affect transport and lives .
It is based on measurement of the product of the radioactive decay of an isotope of potassium ( K ) into argon ( Ar ) .
Time since recrystallization is calculated by measuring the ratio of the amount of 40Ar accumulated to the amount of 40K remaining .
Potassium is a common element found in many materials , such as micas , clay , tephra , and evaporites .
The geomagnetic polarity time scale was calibrated largely using K-Ar dating .
In these materials , the decay product 40Ar is able to escape the liquid ( molten ) rock , but starts to accumulate when the rock solidifies ( recrystallises ) .
Potassium-Argon dating or K-Ar dating is a radiometric dating method used in geochronology and archaeology .
The long half-life of 40K allows the method to be used to calculate the absolute age of samples older than a few thousand years The quickly cooled lavas that make nearly ideal samples for K-Ar dating also preserve a record of the direction and intensity of the local magnetic field as the sample cooled past the Curie point of iron .
The body fat content of a bearded seal is 30-40 % .
Just before the pups are weaned , a new mating cycle takes place .
Bearded seals give birth in the spring .
Further south , in Alaska , most pups are born in late April .
Their whiskers serve as feelers in the soft bottom sediments .
By the time they are weaned , the pups have grown to about one hundred kilograms .
Both sexes are about the same size .
They enter the water only hours after they are born , and quickly become very good divers .
Features of this earless seal include square front flippers and thick bristles on its muzzle .
Pups up to one year old will venture much deeper , diving as deep as 450 m ( 1,480 ft ) .
Pups consume an average of eight liters of milk a day .
The bearded seal is unique in the subfamily Phocinae in having two pairs of teats .
Occasionally the face and neck are reddish-brown .
Females ovulate at the end of their lactation period , but stay close to their pups , ready to defend them if necessary .
Bearded seal pups are born with a greyish-brown fur with scattered patches of white on the back and head .
The bearded seal ( Erignathus barbatus ) , also called the square flipper seal , is a medium-sized pinniped .
Bearded seals are a main food source for polar bears and for the Inuit of the Arctic coast .
Bearded seals feed on a variety of small prey found along the ocean floor , including clams , squid , and fish .
During this time the pups grow at an average rate of 3.3 kg per day .
Fossils indicate that , during the Pleistocene epoch , bearded seals went as far south as South Carolina .
Pups are born on small drifting ice floes in shallow waters .
They like shallow coastal areas no more than 300 m ( 980 ft ) deep .
Adults are greyish-brown in color , darker on the back .
During the mating season , male seals will `` sing '' .
They are 200 kg ( 441 lb ) to 430 kg ( 948 lb ) in weight .
Males live in the same areas from one year to the next .
In the Canadian Arctic , seal pupping is in May .
This sound may attract females , or may be used by the males to say what territory is theirs or their readiness for breeding .
The Flute is a musical instrument .
Sometimes there is 1 piccolo which plays an octave higher , or an alto flute which plays a fifth lower than the flute .
In addition , there are other flutes like piccolos , alto flutes , and bass flutes .
Most flutes are made of silver .
There are many kinds of flutes .

Aberdeen has two universities , the University of Aberdeen which was founded on 10 February 1495 by Bishop William Elphinstone and Robert Gordon University which was founded in 1910 but has a history dating back to the 1800s .
Each year in August , Aberdeen hosts the Aberdeen International Youth Festival .
It has characteristics of both pound cake and coffee cake .
Amish friendship bread is a type of bread or cake made from a sourdough starter that is often shared in a manner similar to a chain letter .
The process of sharing the starter makes it somewhat like a chain letter .
One cup of starter makes one standard loaf of bread .
It can be used to make many kinds of yeast-based breads , shared with friends , or frozen for future use .
It includes a large amount of sugar and vegetable oil , with a mild cinnamon flavor .
A common recipe using this starter uses one cup ( 240 ml ) of it to make bread .
The flavor of the finished product can be changed by not using cinnamon .
The sweet , cake-like Amish cinnamon bread is a common bread that is made from this starter .

`` Le Fils du Soleil '' ( `` Son of the Sun '' ) is an historical novel which tells the amazing story of Mustapha Zemmouri , better known under the name Estevanico , Moroccan from Azemmour region , slave kidnapped by a Spanish man to America and became one of the first discoverers of Arizona and New Mexico .
Then he turned to fiction , but retaining a strong historical basis .

His biography of Kaddour Benghabrit has been selected by the `` Prix Grand Atlas '' in 2011 .

His work is largely focused on his hometown , Essaouira , which he often calls with it former name Mogador .

2012 is a 2009 American science fiction disaster movie directed and co-written by Roland Emmerich .
It was produced by Centropolis Entertainment , Emmerich 's production company , and distributed by Columbia Pictures .
The plot follows Jackson Curtis ( John Cusack ) as he tries to bring his children , Noah ( Liam James ) and Lilly ( Morgan Lily ) , ex-wife Kate Curtis ( Amanda Peet ) , and her boyfriend , Gordon Silberman ( Thomas McCarthy ) to safety from the destructive events that occur .
They liked its special effects , but were critical of its length ( 158 minutes ) and screenwriting .
Critics gave it mixed reviews .
It made $ 770 million worldwide .

Herman Kahn ( February 15 , 1922 - July 7 , 1983 ) was one of the preeminent futurists of the second half of the twentieth century .
He was known for analyzing the likely consequences of nuclear war and recommending ways to improve survivability .
His theories helped to develop the nuclear strategy of the United States .
As the roof of the mouth was once considered the seat of the sense of taste , palate can also refer to this sense itself , as in the phrase `` a discriminating palate '' .
The palate is divided into two parts , the anterior bony hard palate , and the posterior fleshy soft palate or velum .
A similar structure is found in crocodilia , but , in most other tetrapods , the oral and nasal cavities are not truly separate .
It separates the oral cavity ( mouth ) from the nasal cavity .
By further extension , the flavor of a food ( particularly beer or wine ) may be called its palate .
If the fusion is not complete , it is called a cleft palate .
The palate is the roof of the mouth in humans and other mammals .
The hard palate is formed before birth .
The dragon in the Qing Dynasty came out on national flags .
A Chinese dragon was the symbol of the Emperor of China .
Pope Paul II ( Latin : Paulus Secundus ; 23 February 1417 - 26 July 1471 ) , born Pietro Barbo , was an Italian priest of the Roman Catholic Church and the 212th Pope from 1464 until his death in 1471 .
