The earthly DMB is decided to the ETSI standard ( TS 102 427 and TS 102 428 ) .
Digital Multimedia Broadcasting or DMB is a technology that allows to send digital signals to mobile devices , such as mobile phones .
DMB is based on Eureka 147 DAB standard which is the European standard , and similar competing technologies is the mobile TV standard , DVB-H .
The International Bear Brotherhood Flag is a flag representing the international bear community .
The colors represent all the `` fur colors and nationalities around the world . ''
A claw is made of hard protein called keratin .
Similar appendages that are flat and do not come to a sharp point are called nails instead .
The claw grows outward from the nail matrix at the base of the unguis and the subunguis grows thicker while traveling across the nail bed .
The unguis grows outward faster than the subunguis to make a curve and the thinner sides of the claw wear away faster than their thicker middle , making a more or less sharp point .
This takes several months for human thumbnails .
Every so often , the growth of claws stops and restarts , just like the growth of hair .
Cats are often seen working old layers off on wood or on boards made for the purpose .
A nail that is big enough to hold weight is called a ` hoof ' ( see also Horse hoof .
The unguis is the outside hard layer , which has keratin fibers arranged perpendicular to the direction of growth and in layers at an angle .
Domesticated equids ( horses , donkeys and mules ) usually need regular trimming by a farrier .
The word `` claws '' is most often used in reference to an invertebrate .
Tetrapods use their claws in many ways , such as grasping or killing prey , digging , climbing , and hanging .
The subunguis is the soft , flaky layer , and the grain is parallel to the direction of growth .
In claws , this results in an old layer , and it breaks off .
Many predatory mammals have claws that can hide inside the animal 's paw , especially animals such as the cat .
A primate 's nail only has the unguis ; the subunguis has disappeared .
They are used by some meat eating mammals such as cats and dogs to catch and hold prey , but they may also be used for other things such as digging , climbing trees , and so on , in those and other species .
In hair , this causes the hair to fall out and it is replaced by a new one .
Tetrapods , claws are made of keratin and have of two layers .
It is found at the end of a toe or finger in many mammals , birds , and some reptiles .
A nail is similar to a claw but it is flatter and has a curved edge instead of a point .
However some lemurs have a toilet-claw .

By 1915 , gangrene had set in and her entire right leg was amputated , meaning she was in a wheelchair for several months .

She developed a reputation as a serious actress , getting the nickname `` The Divine Sarah . ''
On 26 March 1923 , Bernhardt died of uremia following kidney failure .

She carried out a successful tour of America in 1915 , and died on returning to France .

Hoffmann is a member of the German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina , the French National Academy of Sciences , the Academia Europaea , the European Molecular Biology Organization ( EMBO ) , the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Russian Academy of Sciences .
He is a research director and member of the board of administrators of the National Center of Scientific Research ( CNRS ) in Strasbourg , France .
Its mammalian homologs , the toll-like receptors , were discovered by Beutler .
Hoffmann was a research assistant at CNRS from 1964 to 1968 , and became a research associate in 1969 .
Between 1978 and 2005 he was Director of the CNRS research unit `` Immune Response and Development in Insects '' , and from 1993 to 2005 he was director of the Institute of Molecular and Cellular Biology of CNRS in Strasbourg .
Jules A. Hoffmann ( born 2 August 1941 ) is a Luxembourg-born French biologist .
Since 1974 he has been a Research Director of CNRS .
Hoffmann discovered the function of the fruit fly Toll gene in innate immunity .
His post-doctoral training was at the Institut für Physiologische Chemie at Philipps-Universität in Marburg an der Lahn , Germany in 1973-1974 .
Toll-like receptors identify constituents of other organisms like fungi and bacteria , and trigger an immune response .
Together with Bruce Beutler , Hoffmann received one-half of the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for `` their discoveries concerning the activation of innate immunity '' .
Hoffmann completed his PhD in biology at the University of Strasbourg in 1969 .
In 2007 , he became President of the French Academy of Sciences .
The Lyside Sulphur can grow from egg to adult in as little as 13 days .
Similar species in the Lyside Sulphur 's range include Queen Alexandra 's Sulphur ( Colias alexandra ) , the Cloudless Sulphur ( Phoebis sennae ) , and the Statira Sulphur ( Phoebis statira ) .
It has 3 or more broods per year in southern Texas .
The chrysalis is a bluish-green color .
In Florida , there have been scattered sightings from July to October .
This butterfly is seen almost all year in southern Texas .
The Cloudless Sulphur is larger .
They vary from a greenish color to bright yellow to almost white .
Greener individuals have a whitish vein in the center of the hind wing .
It may have markings or may not have markings .
The Lyside Sulphur may be found in open , subtropical scrub habitats .
The Lyside Sulphur or Guayacan Sulphur ( Kricogonia lyside ) is a North American and South American butterfly .
The Statira Sulphur has a more yellowish upper side .
It has a whitish spot in the center of the hind wing .
Some individuals also have black borders along the top edges of the fore wing .
In seasons with heavy monsoons , this butterfly is seen in large migrations .
The upper side of the wings is pale yellow .
It is sometimes a resident in southern Florida .
The coloring of the Lyside Sulphur varies .

China continued to be dominated by the Han Dynasty , despite a 14-year interruption by the Xin dynasty under Wang Mang .

During this period Europe , North Africa and the Near East fell under increasing domination by the Roman Empire .
The reforms introduced by Augustus during his long reign stabilized the empire .
The modern periodic law says that `` The properties of elements are periodic function of their atomic number . ''
Elements in the s-block are in the first two periodic table groups .
The elements in group two are called the alkaline earth metals .

English was introduced to Singapore by the British in 1819 , when the British established a port , later a colony , on the island .
English had been the administrative language of the colonial government , and when Singapore gained self-government in 1959 and independence in 1965 , the local government decided to keep English as the working language .
In schools , students are also required to take a Mother Tongue class , where they are either taught Mandarin Chinese , Malay or Tamil .
The use of English as a common language serves to bridge the gap between the diverse ethnic groups in Singapore .
There are many languages spoken in Singapore .
The Singapore government recognizes four official languages : English , Malay , Mandarin , and Tamil .
On February 24 , 2008 , Cink was the runner-up in the WGC-Accenture Match Play Championship played in Marana , Arizona , falling 8 & 7 in the 36-hole final to top-ranked Tiger Woods .
In June 2008 , he reached his highest ever ranking , sixth , in the Official World Golf Rankings with his victory at the Travelers Championship in suburban Hartford .
Cink performed consistently on the Tour over the next few years , picking up another win at the 2000 MCI Classic .
Cink was born in Huntsville , Alabama and grew up in Florence , where he attended Bradshaw High School .
On July 19 , 2009 , Cink won his first major title at the 138th Open Championship at Turnberry , Scotland , defeating 59 year-old Tom Watson by six strokes in a four-hole playoff .
Cink had birdied the 72nd hole while Watson bogeyed , which forced the playoff .
After winning the Mexican Open and three events on the Nike Tour ( now the Nationwide Tour ) in 1996 , Cink joined the PGA Tour in 1997 and won the Canon Greater Hartford Open in his rookie season .
Stewart Ernest Cink ( born May 21 , 1973 ) is an American professional golfer .
He completed high school in 1991 and he attended Georgia Tech in Atlanta , where he played golf for the Yellow Jackets ; he turned professional in 1995 .
Until his victory in the Open Championship in 2009 , 2004 was his career year to date , with a fifth-place finish on the money list and wins at the MCI Heritage and at the WGC-NEC Invitational , which is one of the World Golf Championships events and was the most prestigious win of his career at the time .
He spent 39 weeks in the top 10 of the Official World Golf Rankings from 2004 to 2008 .
Soon after Horton opened the store , he met Ron Joyce , a former Hamilton police constable .
By 1967 , after he had opened up two more stores , he and Tim Horton became full partners in the business .
The chain got 22.6 % of all fast food industry revenues in Canada in 2005 .
The business was started by Tim Horton , who played in the National Hockey League from 1949 until his death in a car accident in 1974 .
In 1965 , Joyce took over the Tim Horton Donut Shop on Ottawa Street North in Hamilton .
TDL Group said in March 2006 , that because they were asked by Chief of the Defense Staff , General Rick Hillier , it would open a store at the Canadian Forces operations base in Kandahar , Afghanistan .
Tim Hortons also has 76 % of the Canadian market for baked goods ( based on the number of customers ) and has 62 % of the Canadian coffee market ( compared to Starbucks , who is the second largest with 7 % ) .
Joyce expanded the chain quickly in geography and in product selection , opening the 500th store in Aylmer , Quebec , in 1991 .
Tim Hortons Inc. is a Canadian fast food restaurant known for its coffee and doughnuts .
The new Kandahar store opened on June 29 2006 , in a 40 ft trailer on the military base .
In 1967 Tim Horton joined with investor Ron Joyce , who quickly took over running the company and expanded the chain into a multi-million dollar franchise .
After Horton 's death in 1974 , Joyce bought the company from the Horton family and took over as the only owner of the now forty stores .
Ron Joyce 's very fast expansion of the Tim Hortons business brought about two major changes in the coffee and doughnut restaurant market : independent doughnut shops in Canada were almost wiped out , and Canada 's per person ratio of doughnut shops rose past those of all other countries .
The companies first store opened in 1964 in Hamilton , Ontario under the name `` Tim Horton Donuts '' ( the word donut would later be dropped and the company name ended up as just `` Tim Horton 's '' , and later was changed to `` Tim Hortons '' without the apostrophe ) .
Tim Hortons has many stores on or near many Canadian Forces Bases .
It was started in 1964 in Hamilton , Ontario by Canadian hockey player Tim Horton .
The company opened twice as many Canadian stores as did McDonald 's and sales also are bigger than those of McDonald 's Canadian restaurants as of 2002 .
Wallace studied the distribution of flora and fauna in the Amazon Basin and the Malay Archipelago in the mid-19th century .
Wallace and Sclater saw biogeography as a source of support for the theory of evolution .
The scientific theory of biogeography grows out of the work of Alexander von Humboldt ( 1769-1859 ) , Hewett Cottrell Watson ( 1804-1881 ) , Alphonse de Candolle ( 1806-1893 ) , Alfred Russel Wallace ( 1823-1913 ) , Philip Lutley Sclater ( 1829-1913 ) , and other biologists and explorers .
Otherwise , the field of biogeography would be a purely descriptive one .
Key findings , such as the sharp difference in fauna either side of the Wallace Line , can only be understood in this light .
Genome analysis allows scientists to test theories about the origin and dispersal of populations , such as island species .
They showed that the species richness of an area could be predicted if one knew the habitat area , immigration rate and extinction rate .
This spurred the development of conservation biology .

Janko Prunk ( pronunciation ( info \* help ) ) , ( born December 30 , 1942 ) is a Slovenian historian of modern history .
From 1966 to 1995 , he collaborated with the Institute for modern history in Ljubljana .
His book A brief history of Slovenia : Historical background of the Republic of Slovenia is one of the basic full works on modern Slovenian history .
In 1984 and 1988 , he was awarded the scholarships by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation , which enabled him to continue his studies in Cologne and Freiburg .
He became very critical of the then prime minister Janez Janša , whom he accused of being a `` liberal with an authoritative touch '' who aspires at becoming a `` Slovenian Piłsudski '' .
He has also written on the history of political movements in Slovenia from the end of 19th century until World War II , especially with Slovene Christian socialism and the history of Slovenian national questions .
He obtained his PhD in 1976 with thesis on the relationship between the Slovenian Christian Socialist movement and the Communist Party of Slovenia within the Liberation Front of the Slovenian People , which at the time was a somehow problematic topic .
Prunk was born in the small village of Loka pri Zidanem Mostu near the town of Sevnica in central Slovenia , in what was then the German-occupied Lower Styria .
In 2005 , he was appointed by the Foreign Minister Dimitrij Rupel as president of the Slovene-Croatian Historical Commission , formed by the governments of the two countries to shed light on the history of the relations between the two nations .
He now works as a professor at the Faculty for Social Sciences of the University of Ljubljana .
Between 1992 and 1993 , he served as Minister for Slovenes outside Slovenia in the first coalition cabinet of Janez Drnovšek .
Janko Prunk has written over 350 specialized articles and several books .
As an early admirer of Jože Pučnik , he joined the Slovenian Social Democratic Union after the democratization of Slovenia .
He graduated at the University of Ljubljana in 1966 and obtained his Master degree from the same institution in 1972 .
Between 2004 and 2008 , he served as chairman of the Party 's internal Committee for Education Policies ; he quit for disagreements over the Government policy favoring private universities .
He has also been actively involved in politics .
He has written on politology , modern history , modern political formations , and the history of social and political thought in Slovenia .

His mother , Luise Therese Sophie Schliemann , died in 1831 when Heinrich was 9 years old .

Mendeleev was one of the founders , in 1869 , of the Russian Chemical Society .
While there he became a science master of the Simferopol gymnasium № 1 .
Mendeleev was born in village of Verkhnie Aremzyani , near Tobolsk , to Ivan Pavlovich Mendeleev and Maria Dmitrievna Mendeleeva ( née Kornilieva ) .
He returned with fully restored health to Saint Petersburg in 1857 .
He worked on the theory and practice of protectionist trade and on agriculture .
His grandfather was Pavel Maximovich Sokolov , a priest of Russian Orthodox Church from the Tver region .
At the age of 13 , after the death of his father and the destruction of his mother 's factory by fire , Mendeleev attended the Gymnasium in Tobolsk .
In 1863 there were 56 known elements with a new element being discovered at a rate of approximately one each year .
After graduation , tuberculosis caused him to move to the Crimean Peninsula on the northern coast of the Black Sea in 1855 .
In 1849 , the now poor Mendeleev family went to Saint Petersburg , where he entered the Main Pedagogical Institute in 1850 .
The Russian chemist and science historian L.A. Tchugayev called him `` a chemist of genius , first-class physicist , a fruitful researcher in the fields of hydrodynamics , meteorology , geology , certain branches of chemical technology ( explosives , petroleum , and fuels , for example ) and other disciplines adjacent to chemistry and physics , a thorough expert of chemical industry and industry in general , and an original thinker in the field of economy '' .
Mendeleev is thought to be the youngest of 14 siblings , but the exact number differs between sources .
Ivan , with his brothers and sisters , got new family names while attending theological seminary .
Another was Lothar Meyer , who published a work in 1864 , describing 28 elements .

Pegomastax ( `` strong jaw '' ) is a genus of small heterodontosaur dinosaur discovered in Lower Jurassic rocks in South Africa .
The type species is P. africana .
Like most other heterodontosaurs , Pegomastax had an enlarged canine-like tooth at the beginning of the lower jaw 's tooth row , which may have been used for defense .
Paul Sereno , who had recognized it as unusual in the 1980s , published a description in 2012 .
Pegomastax differed from other heterodontosaurs by details of the skull .
It takes its name from the heavily populated City of Leicester , its traditional administrative center , although the City of Leicester is today administered separately from the rest of Leicestershire .
It is named after Calliope , the Greek Muse of epic poetry .
Lightcurve analysis indicates that Kalliope 's pole most likely points towards ecliptic coordinates ( β , λ ) = ( -23 ° , 20 ° ) with a 10 ° uncertainty , which gives Kalliope an axial tilt of 103 ° .
Kalliope also has a low radar albedo , which is again inconsistent with a metallic surface .
Linus was found on August 29 , 2001 by Jean-Luc Margot and Michael E. Brown , while another team also independently detected the moon 3 days later .
22 Kalliope is a big main belt asteroid of the M-type , found by J. R. Hind on November 16 , 1852 .
Kalliope has one known moon , Linus , or ( 22 ) Kalliope I Linus .
Furthermore , spectroscopic studies have shown evidence of hydrated minerals and silicates , which indicate that the surface is stony .
Kalliope 's rotation is then a bit retrograde .
It is quite big being 30-40 km in diameter , and would be a sizeable asteroid by itself .
Kalliope is somewhat stretched , approximately 180 km in diameter , and slightly asymmetric , as evidenced by resolved images taken with the VLT at the European Southern Observatory While its spectrum is an M-type , Kalliope does not appear to be metallic , similarly to other M-types such as 21 Lutetia , for example .

Some CR groups have looked to Celtic languages for a more culturally specific name for the tradition , or for their branch of the tradition .
These celebrations often involve bonfires , dances , songs , divination and children 's games .
More formal or mystical CR rituals are often based on traditional techniques of interacting with the Otherworld , such as the act of making offerings of food , drink and art to the spirits of the land , ancestral spirits , and the Celtic deities .
No list can completely cover all the recommended works , but this is a small sample of sources used .
Many CRs view each act of daily life as a form of ritual , and they accompany daily activities with traditional prayers , chants and songs from sources such as the Scottish Gaelic Carmina Gadelica or manuscript collections of ancient Irish or Welsh poetry .
Celtic Reconstructionists rely on primary mythological texts , as well as surviving folklore , for the basis of their religious practices .
While Celtic Reconstructionism was the earliest name in use , and is still used the most often , other names for a Celtic Reconstructionist approach have also come into use , with varying degrees of success .
Community rituals are usually based on traditional community celebrations found in folkloric collections by authors such as Marian McNeill , Kevin Danaher or John Gregorson Campbell .
They may place these altars at outdoor , natural locations such as wells , streams , and special trees .
There are groups who now described their traditions as Pàganachd ( `` Paganism , Heathenism '' in Scottish Gaelic ) or the Irish version , Págánacht .
Some CRs practice divination , such as the taking of omens from the shapes of clouds or the behavior of birds and animals .
CR ritual structures are based on the ancient Celtic idea of the `` Three Realms '' - Land , Sea and Sky - with the fire of inspiration seen as a central , uniting force .
Some Gaelic-oriented groups use the two terms somewhat interchangeably , or further modify these terms to describe the CR sub-tradition practiced by their particular group , such as Pàganachd Allaidh ( `` Wild Paganism '' ) or Pàganachd Bhandia ( `` Paganism of Goddesses '' ) , both used by Gaelic Reconstructionist groups on the East Coast of the US .
The first person to write about being a `` Celtic Reconstructionist Pagan '' was Kym Lambert ní Dhoireann .
In the late 1990 's , members of Imbas , a Celtic Reconstructionist group in Seattle , began promoting the name Senistrognata , which they say means `` the ancestral customs of the Celtic peoples '' in reconstructed Old Celtic .
The angle tint tool has a slightly curved tip that is commonly used in printmaking .
Each cell creates one printing dot later in the process .
Gravers come in a variety of shapes and sizes that give different line types when used .
The engraving process with diamonds is state of the art since the 1960s .
Engraving machines such as the K500 or K6 by Hell Gravure Systems use a diamond `` pen '' to cut cells .
In the U.S. Bureau of Engraving and Printing , more than one engraver will work on the same printing plate , making it nearly impossible for any person to duplicate all the engraving on almost any banknote or document .
The result may be a decorative piece in itself , as when silver , gold or steel are engraved , or may provide a printing plate of copper or another metal , for printing images on paper which are also called engravings .
Now , laser engraving machines are being made and even today the mechanical cutting has proven its strength in economical terms and quality .
Engravers use a steel tool called a burin to cut the picture or pattern into the surface , mostly a copper plate .
Florentine liners are flat-bottomed tools with multiple lines on them , used to do work on larger areas .
Because of the high level of detail that can be done by a master engraver , faking engraved designs is almost impossible , and modern banknotes are almost always engraved , as are plates for printing money , checks , bonds and other papers that should not be faked .
Flat gravers are used for doing work on letters , as well as most musical instrument engraving work .
Round gravers are commonly used on silver as well as other hard-to-cut metals such as nickel and steel .
A K6 can have up to 18 engraving heads each cutting 8,000 cells per second to an accuracy of 0.1 µm and below .
It has long been replaced by photography in its commercial uses and , is nowadays much less common in printmaking , where it has been almost completely replaced by etching and other techniques .
Engraving is so fine that a normal printer can not make the detail of hand engraved images properly .
Engraving is putting a design onto a hard , flat surface , by carving into it .
They are of course fully computer controlled and the whole process of cylinder making is fully automatic .
Howard Walter Florey , Baron Florey OM FRS ( 29 November 1898 - 21 February 1968 ) was an Australian pathologist who shared the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 1945 , for his study into penicillin .
He died from a heart attack in 1968 .
He was born in Adelaide , South Australia .
From 1962 he was Provost of The Queen 's College at Oxford .
he had a big role in starting the Australian National University ( ANU ) , especially the John Curtin School of Medical Research .
He was appointed a knight bachelor , and later a baron .

Albatrosses have been described as `` the most legendary of all birds '' .
Many Buller 's Albatrosses and Black-footed Albatrosses nest under trees in open forest .
Albatrosses take several years to get their full adult feathers .
Albatross chicks take a long time to fledge ( learn how to fly ) .
The feet have no last toe and the three other toes are all webbed .
Another threat to albatrosses are introduced species , like rats or feral cats ( cats that live without being cared for by people ) , which attack the albatross or its chicks and eggs .
Most albatrosses are found in the southern hemisphere from Antarctica to Australia , South Africa and South America .
For example , on Gough Island , the chicks of Tristan Albatrosses are attacked and eaten alive by house mice .
The great albatrosses take over a year to raise a chick .
One important step towards protecting albatrosses and other seabirds is the 2001 treaty by the Agreement on the Conservation of Albatrosses and Petrels , which eight countries , Australia , Ecuador , New Zealand , Spain , South Africa , France , Peru and the United Kingdom , agreed with .
They were once known as Goonie birds or Gooney birds , especially the albatrosses in the North Pacific .
In all albatross species , both parents incubate the egg from between one day and three weeks .
The tubes of all albatrosses are on the sides of the bill .
Between 15 % and 65 % of those who fledged survive to find their mate after .
During this time the parents feed the chick small meals .
All birds have a large gland at the top part of their bill , above their eyes .
The Waved Albatross , however , does not make a nest but instead moves its egg around the pair 's territory , as much as 50 m ( 160 ft ) .
From the 21 albatross species found by the IUCN on their list , 19 are threatened , and the other two are very near to being threatened as well .
Albatrosses lay one egg , white with reddish brown spots .
As Europeans began to explore the world , they too began to hunt albatross .
In Portuguese , the word still presently used for the bird , albatroz , came from the English albatross .
When taking-off , albatrosses need to run first to help the wing make lift .
This is one of their strongest instinct , and the study of Laysan Albatross showed that the normal distance between the place where it was hatched and the place where the bird made its own territory was 22m ( 72 ft ) .
In the case of more bigger albatrosses , it can take up to 280 days .
Conservationists have also worked on taking away the introduced species to protect the albatrosses .
Great Albatrosses are among the largest of flying birds .

The last one , the Waved Albatross , is in the Galapagos Islands and finds food in the coast of South America .
The parents both take turns to go and find food , that are about 12 % of their body weight ( around 600 g ( 21 oz ) ) .
When they do this , it takes a lot of energy , and the adult can lose as much as 83 g ( 2.9 oz ) of body weight a day .
The larger eggs weigh from 200-510 g ( 7.1-18 oz ) .

Case-series may refer to the qualititative study of the experience of a single patient , or small group of patients with a similar diagnosis , or to a statistical technique comparing periods during which patients are exposed to some factor with the potential to produce illness with periods when they are unexposed .
His identification of the Broad Street pump as the cause of the Soho epidemic is the classic example of epidemiology .

This has been perceived as a major event in the history of public health and can be regarded as the founding event of the science of epidemiology .

He has also drawn the distinction between ` epidemic ' and ` endemic ' to distinguish between diseases that are ` visited upon ' a population ( epidemic ) from those that ` reside within ' a population ( endemic ) .
In 1847 Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis brought down infant mortality at a Vienna hospital by instituting a disinfection procedure .
The term has expanded considerably in scope since to cover the description and causation of not only epidemic disease , but of disease in general , and even many non-disease health-related conditions , such as high blood pressure and obesity .
Cohort studies select subjects based on their exposure status .
Epidemiological studies can only go to prove that an agent could have caused disease in population , but not that it did cause , an effect in any particular case .
In the early 20th century , mathematical methods were introduced into epidemiology by Ronald Ross and others .
Hippocrates is viewed as the father of epidemiology as the first who has examined the relationships between the occurrence of disease and environmental influences .
Epidemiologists also study the interaction of diseases in a population .
Dr. John Snow investigated into the causes of the 19th Century Cholera epidemics .
The term ` epidemiology ' has first been used to describe the study of epidemics in 1802 by the Spanish physician Villalba .
But the term is used in studies of zoological populations , although there is the term ` epizoology ' , and it has also been applied to studies of plant populations .
Epidemiologists rely on biology ( to better understand disease processes ) , biostatistics ( to design and understand good studies ) , Geographic Information Science ( to store data and map disease patterns ) and social science disciplines ( to understand `` big picture '' causes ) .

Gaia will monitor each of its target stars about 70 times over a period of five years .
It will be operated in a Lissajous orbit around the Sun-Earth L2 Lagrangian point .

There are six games in total - three where the player has to follow the command , one memory game that uses a combination of colors and numbers , a code buster game and a game called Pass Attack where players have to make up their own pattern .
The spherical unit has six colored knobs - purple , red , green , white , orange and yellow - with numbers on them , and a blue base .
The voice calls out a color , a number , or both , depending on the game selected , and the player flips the unit so that the correct knob is facing upwards .
A second version was released in 2002 with a translucent black base .
After every four points , the game becomes faster .
The game was the most popular in Duracell 's Kids ' Choice National Toy Survey in 1996 .
If the player responds incorrectly , the round is ended and the unit will make a laughing sound .

Razor shells have a fragile shell , with open ends .
The razor shell has been known to reach 23 centimetres ( 9.1 in ) in length .
The inner surface is white with a purple tinge and the foot is creamy white with brown lines .
The razor shell lives under the sand , using its powerful foot to dig to a safe depth .
It can easily be confused with the slightly shorter 15 centimetres ( 5.9 in ) and more curved E. ensis ( in which both front and back are curved in parallel ) .
The shell is smooth on the outside and whitish in color , with vertical and horizontal reddish-brown or purplish-brown markings separated by a diagonal line .
The dorsal margin is straight while the ventral margin is curved .
Deflation of the foot then pulls the shell down .
The razor shell also squirts water down into the sand , removing loose sand from its path .
The periostracum is olive-green .
A digging cycle involves the muscular foot ( which takes up a large part of the body ) and the opening and closing of the valve and one end .
Ensis arcuatus prefers coarser sand than its relatives E. ensis and E. siliqua .
The presence of the shell under the sand is revealed by a keyhole-shaped hole in the sand , made by its siphons during suspension feeding for plankton .
The foot is inflated hydraulically , and pushed down into the sand to anchor the animal .
In the razor shell sexual development is highly synchronous : eggs and sperms are shed at the same time .
Ensis , of the family Pharidae , is found on sandy beaches in Northern Europe and Eastern Canada , such as Prince Edward Island .
In winter and spring consecutive spawns take place , interrupted by periods when more eggs and sperm are produced .
Razor shells , also called razor clams , are bivalves with the shape of an old-fashioned cut-throat razor .
The digging has six stages , repeated .
Heinrich Anton de Bary ( 26 January 1831 - 19 January 1888 ) was a German surgeon , botanist , microbiologist , and mycologist ( fungal systematics and physiology ) .
He is considered a founding father of plant pathology ( phytopathology ) as well as the founder of modern mycology .
His extensive and careful studies of the life history of fungi and contribution to the understanding of algae and higher plants were landmarks of biology .
He traced the stages through which they grew and reproduced and the adaptations which enabled them to survive drought and winter .
De Bary studied the formation of lichens , the association between a fungus and an alga .
He carefully studied the morphology of moulds , yeasts , and fungi and he established mycology as an independent science .
He coined the word ` symbiosis ' in 1879 in his monograph as `` the living together of unlike organisms '' .
China Airlines Flight 611 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Taipei to Hong Kong , China .
However , two Cathay Pacific planes nearby received flight 611 's emergency location-indicator signals .
A dyke ( or dike ) in geology is a type of later vertical rock between older layers of rock .

He went to Harvard College .
One of his last acts as president was to make John Marshall the Chief Justice of the United States .
He helped Thomas Jefferson write the United States Declaration of Independence .
During the American Revolutionary War , Adams helped make peace with Great Britain .

It is said that smugglers who landed on the beach in the middle of the night could judge `` exactly where they were '' by the size of the shingle .
Westwards the shingle forms a straight line along the coast , enclosing the Fleet , a shallow tidal lagoon .
At the eastern end of the beach at the village of Chiswell , against the cliffs of the Isle of Portland , the beach curves round sharply to form Chesil Cove .
The beach and the Fleet are part of the Jurassic Coast , a UNESCO World Heritage Site , and the location for a book , On Chesil Beach by Ian McEwan .
Its name is derived from the Old English ceosel or cisel , meaning `` gravel '' or `` shingle '' .
This part of the beach protects the low-lying village from flooding .

The vacuoles are extremely small .
The cell wall is a very thin primary cell wall .
Specifically , an active apical meristem lays down a growing root or shoot behind itself , pushing itself forward .
Meristematic cells are packed closely together without intercellular cavities .
The cells are small and protoplasm fills the cell completely .
Apical meristems are very small , compared to the cylinder-shaped lateral meristems .
It begins growth of new cells in young seedlings at the tips of roots and shoots ( forming buds , among other things ) .
Plant cells which are ( differentiated ) generally can not divide or produce cells of a different type .
There are two types of secondary meristems :
The apical meristem , or growing tip , is found in the buds and growing tips of roots in plants .
They are incompletely or not at all differentiated , and are capable of continued cell division .
The cytoplasm does not contain plastids ( such as chloroplasts , but they are there in rudimentary form ( ` proplastids ' ) .
Meristematic cells have the same function for plants as stem cells have for animals .
They are in parts of the plant where growth can take place .
Apical meristems may differentiate into three kinds of primary meristem : These meristems are responsible for primary growth , or an increase in length or height .

In comparison to earlier proboscids , Gomphotherium had fewer molars ; the remaining ones had high ridges to expand their grinding surface .
These animals probably lived in swamps or near lakes , using their tusks to dig or scrape up aquatic vegetation .
It survived into the Pliocene , and its remains have been found in Chile , France , Germany , Austria , Kansas , Tennessee , Pakistan , Kenya and Bosnia and Herzegovina .
Compared to elephants , the skull was more elongated and low , indicating that the animal had a short trunk , rather like a tapir 's .
Unlike modern elephants , the upper tusks were covered by a layer of enamel .
Gomphotherium lived in dry wooded regions near lakes .
Gomphotherium stood around 3 metres ( 9.8 ft ) high with an estimated weight of 4-5 tons , and looked similar to a modern elephant .
However , it had four tusks ; two on the upper jaw and two on the long lower jaw .
The lower tusks are parallel and shaped like a shovel .

This happens when the Pluto-Charon orbital plane is edge-on as seen from Earth , which only happens at twice in Pluto 's 248-year orbital period .
Any final doubts were erased when Pluto and Charon entered a five-year period of mutual eclipses between 1985 and 1990 .
Pictures showing Pluto and Charon as separate disks were taken for the first time by the Hubble Space Telescope in the 1990s .
Later observations of Pluto were able to figure out that the bulge was due to a smaller body .
Charon is a moon of the dwarf planet Pluto .
The orbit of the bulge fit in with Pluto 's rotation period , which was already known from Pluto 's light curve .
Later , after a new technology called adaptive optics was discovered , it was possible to see Pluto and Charon as separate disks using ground-based telescopes .
It was very lucky that one of these intervals happened to occur so soon after Charon 's discovery .

George Herbert Leigh Mallory ( June 18 , 1886 - June 8\/June 9 1924 ) was a British mountaineer who took part in three expeditions to Mount Everest in the early 1920 's .
In 1910 he began teaching at Charterhouse School , Godalming , Surrey , where he met the poet Robert Graves , then a pupil ; in his autobiography , Goodbye to All That , Graves remembered Mallory , who acted as best man at Robert Graves ' wedding in 1918 , fondly both for his encouragement of Grave 's interest in literature in poetry and his instruction in climbing .
After the war he returned to Charterhouse , resigning in 1921 to take part in the first Everest expedition .
Mallory was born in Mobberly , Cheshire , the son of Herbert Leigh Mallory ( 1846 - 1943 ) , a clergyman who changed his name to Leigh-Mallory in 1914 .
Mallory 's fate was unknown for 75 years until his body was discovered in 1999 .
George Mallory was famous for replying to the question `` Why do you want to climb Mount Everest ? ''
In 1896 , Mallory went to Glengorse , a boarding school in Eastbourne on the south coast of England , having already transferred from a school in West Kirby .
In his second - to - last year at Winchester , he was introduced to rock climbing and mountaineering by a master , R.L.G Irving , who took a small number of pupils climbing in the Alps every year .

Following the destructive assault of the Saxons , the survivors gather together under the leadership of Ambrosius , who is described as : '' ... a gentleman who , perhaps alone of the Romans , had survived the shock of this notable storm .
His descendants in our day have become greatly inferior to their grandfather 's ( avita ) excellence . ''
However , this victory was not decisive : `` Sometimes the Saxons and sometimes the citizens ( meaning the Romano-British inhabitants ) were victorious . ''
According to Gildas , Ambrosius organised the survivors into an armed force and achieved the first military victory over the Saxon invaders .
Certainly his parents , who had worn the purple , were slain by it .
Ambrosius Aurelianus is one of the few people that Gildas ( a sixth century historian who lived in South-west Britain and wrote `` De Excidio Britanniae '' , which focused largely on the history of Christian Britain ) identifies by name in his sermon De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae , and the only one named from the 5th century .
He also appeared independently in the legends of the Britons , beginning with the 9th-century `` Historia Brittonum '' , written by Nennius .

The Stone Roses are an English rock band .

In the United States , there is no federal law stating a required age to be tattooed .
Most such tattooists will allow a parent or guardian to give written or oral consent in person .
When a person reaches the age of 18 in the U.S. , they are legally considered an adult .
The artist may also choose to place addition restrictions , such as refusing any clients under a specific age even with parental consent , or limiting the type and\/or location of where they are willing to tattoo a minor ( such as refusing any work around intimate parts of the body ) .
Individual tattooists may choose to set age restrictions for their business as a precaution against lawsuits .
Many states require that the person being tattooed is an adult over 18 , but some states do allow people under that age to be tattooed with parental consent .
Minor must have parental consent .
Must be 18 .

The last scimitar cat could have survived in North America until 10,000 years ago .
In Eurasia it survived until about 30,000 years ago .
It first became extinct in Africa some 1.5 million years ago .
In South America it is only known from a few remains in the northern ( Venezuela ) , in the mid-Pleistocene .

The Kingdom of Sophene ( Armenian : Ծոփքի Թագավորութուն ) was an ancient Armenian kingdom .
Found sometime around the 3rd century B.C. the kingdom stayed independent until 90 's B.C. when Tigranes the great conquered these territories as part of his empire .

Gichin Funakoshi ( 船越 義珍 , Funakoshi Gichin ?
, 10 November 1868-26 April 1957 ) was the founder of Shotokan , which is the most widely known school or style of karate .
Many of his works can be found in Deutsches Historisches Museum , Akademie der Künste and the German Federal Archive .
For the social democratic newspaper Dresdner Volkszeitung he designed the masthead .
The German national picture archive of arts at the University of Marburg documents 34 of his posters from that time .
Friedrich Kurt Fiedler ( 8 March 1894 - 11 November 1950 ) was a German graphic designer .
Fiedler counts today as one of the leading poster artists of post-war East Germany .
Kurt Fiedler was born in the little village Eichbusch near Dresden as a son of a carpenter .
During World War I Fiedler served as front-line soldier in France .
Among his best known pieces of that period is Junkerland in Bauernhand , a movie poster designed for the DEFA .
From 1911 to 1915 Fiedler got a grant to study as master scholar of Richard Guhr and Josef Goller .
On occasion of the World Advertising Congress 1929 in Berlin , Fiedler was awarded for his poster design .
After 1930 Fiedler became known for some of his drawings , especially of children .
Together with the later known painter Hermann Glöckner he attended around 1910 the evening classes of the Kunstgewerbeschule Dresden .
During the Weimar Republic he became known for his book and poster designs .
The home of Kurt Fiedler was completely destroyed during Bombing of Dresden in World War II on 13 February 1945 .
Until the end of Nazi Germany he earned his money with technical drawings at the Dresden University of Technology .
During World War II Kurt Fiedler served as translator for French prisoners of war .
The oriental plane is found naturally in riverine settings , together with such trees as alder , willow and poplar .
Some accounts extend its native range to Iberia in the west , and to the Himalayas in the east .
However , it is quite capable of survival and success in dry soils once it is established .
Platanus orientalis , the Oriental plane , is a large , deciduous tree of the Platanaceae family .
The native range of the Oriental plane is Eurasia from the Balkans to as far east as at least Iran .
Following Greek usage it is called Platane or related names in Europe .
Such rices have the ability to absorb liquids and to release starch and so they are stickier than the long grain varieties .
There are many different risotto recipes with different ingredients , but they are all based on rice of an appropriate variety cooked in a standard procedure .
They have slightly different properties .
Many variations have their own names :
Rice designations of Superfino , Semifino and Fino refer to the size and shape ( specifically the length and the narrowness ) of the grains , and not the quality .
When it has evaporated , the heat is raised to medium high and very hot stock is gradually added in small amounts while stirring gently , almost constantly : stirring loosens the starch molecules from the outside of the rice grains into the surrounding liquid , creating a smooth creamy-textured liquid .
It is one of the most common ways of cooking rice in Italy .
Other varieties like Roma , Baldo , Ribe and Originario may be used but will not have the creaminess of the traditional dish .
These varieties are considered better for soups and other non-risotto rice dishes and for making sweet rice desserts .
For example , Carnaroli is less likely than Vialone Nano to get overcooked , but the latter , being smaller , cooks faster and absorbs condiments better .
Properly cooked risotto is rich and creamy but still with some resistance or bite : al dente , and with separate grains .
The principal varieties used in Italy are Arborio , Baldo , Carnaroli , Maratelli , Padano , Roma , and Vialone Nano .
It must be eaten at once as it continues to cook in its own heat and can become too dry with the grains too soft .
It is served on flat dishes and it should easily spread out but not have excess watery liquid around the perimeter .
It may be removed from the heat a few minutes earlier , and left to cook with its residual heat .
The traditional texture is fairly fluid , or all ` onda ( `` wavy , or flowing in waves '' ) .
The rice is first cooked briefly in a soffritto of onion and butter or olive oil to coat each grain in a film of fat , this is called tostatura ; white or red wine is added and has to be absorbed by the grains .
There is even , exceptionally , an Italian strawberry risotto .
Risotto can be made using many kinds of vegetable , meat , fish , seafood and legumes , and different types of wine and cheese may be used .
A high-starch ( amylopectin ) , low-amylose round medium - or short-grain rice is usually used to make risotto .
The broth may be meat - , fish - , or vegetable-based .
Many types of risotto contain Parmesan cheese , butter , and onion .
Risotto is normally a primo ( first course ) , served on its own before the main course , but risotto alla milanese is often served together with ossobuco alla milanese .
At that point it is taken off the heat for the mantecatura when diced cold butter and finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese are vigorously stirred in to make the texture as creamy and smooth as possible .
Carnaroli , Maratelli and Vialone Nano are considered to be the best ( and most expensive ) varieties , with different users preferring one over the other .
Risotto is a class of Italian rice dishes cooked in broth to a creamy consistency .
The position of the hymenium is traditionally the first characteristic used in the classification and identification of different mushrooms .
The hymenium is the layer of tissue on the hymenophore of a fungal fruiting body , where cells develop into basidia or asci .

A line segment is part of a line .

Anna Moffo ( June 27 , 1932 - March 9 , 2006 ) was an Italian American operatic soprano particularly associated with lyric-coloratura roles in Italian and French operas , she was admired as much for her vocal gifts as her great beauty and affecting stage presence .
Born in Wayne , Pennsylvania , to Italian parents , she first studied at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia , with Eufemia Giannini-Gregory , and later at the Accademia di Santa Cecilia in Rome , Italy , with Mercedes Llopart and Luigi Ricci .

Galileo used this system in his notebooks but never actually published it .
On January 7 , 1610 , Galileo wrote a letter containing the first mention of Jupiter 's moons .
In these observations , he found a fourth body , and also observed that the four were not fixed stars , but rather were orbiting Jupiter .
Galileo 's Sidereus Nuncius ( Starry Messenger ) , which announced celestial observations through his telescope , does not mention Copernican heliocentrism , a theory that placed the Sun at the center of the universe .
At the time , he only saw three of them , and he believed them to be fixed stars near Jupiter .
The discovery was announced in the Sidereus Nuncius ( ` Starry Messenger ' ) , published in Venice in March 1610 , less than two months after the first observations .
Galileo refused to use Marius 's names and invented the numbering scheme that is still used nowadays , in parallel with proper moon names .
Nevertheless , Galileo believed in the Copernican theory .
Galileo Galilei found what came to be known as the Galilean moons around December 1609 or January 1610 .
At the grand-duke 's suggestion , Galileo changed the name to Medicea Sidera ( ` the Medici stars ' ) , honoring all four Medici brothers ( Cosimo , Francesco , Carlo , and Lorenzo ) .
Galileo also developed a method of determining longitude based on the timing of the orbits of the Galilean moons .
More importantly , the discovery of celestial bodies orbiting something other than the Earth dealt a blow to the then-accepted Ptolemaic world system .
Marius claimed to have found the moons at the same time as Galileo : he named them after lovers of the god Zeus ( the Greek equivalent of Jupiter ) : Io , Europa , Ganymede and Callisto , in his Mundus Jovialis , published in 1614 .
The numbers run from Jupiter outward , thus I , II , III and IV for Io , Europa , Ganymede and Callisto respectively .
Galileo 's discovery proved the importance of the telescope as a tool for astronomers .
Galileo called his discovery the Cosmica Sidera ( ` Cosimo 's stars ' ) , in honor of Cosimo II de ' Medici ( 1590-1621 ) , grand-duke of Tuscany , whose patronage he wanted .
The Galilean moons are the four satellites of Jupiter found by Galileo Galilei : Io , Europa , Ganymede , and Callisto .
As a result of improvements he made to the telescope , Galileo was able to see celestial bodies better than ever before in human history .
It showed there were objects in space to be found , which were not seen by the naked eye .
A Chinese historian of astronomy claims that Chinese astronomer Gan De observed one of Jupiter 's moons in 362 BC , but without a telescope it is difficult to see how this was done .
They are by far the biggest of the many moons of Jupiter .

The foreskin is a fold of skin that covers the glans penis .
The outside of the foreskin is like normal skin but the inside of the foreskin is a membrane like the inside of an eyelid or mouth .

Seán Thomas O'Kelly ( Irish : Seán Tomás Ó Ceallaigh ; 25 August 1882 - 23 November 1966 ) was the second President of Ireland .
He escaped from detention in Fairfield in the UK , and returned to Ireland .
Along with other Sinn Féin MPs he refused to take his seat in the British House of Commons .
He retired at the end of his second term in 1959 , to be replaced by his old friend , Éamon de Valera .
He joined the National Library of Ireland in 1898 as a junior assistant .
During his second term he visited many nations in Europe and spoke to the United States Congress in 1959 .
Instead former Fianna Fáil TD , Domhnall Ua Buachalla from County Kildare , would be the last Governor-General .
O'Kelly was elected Sinn Féin MP for College Green in the 1918 British general election .
Ó Ceallaigh left the cabinet in 1945 when he was elected President of Ireland in a popular vote of the people , defeating two other candidates .
Stunts such as withdrawing the Irish Army 's band from playing at diplomatic functions which the Governor-General attended , or in one notorious case the sight of O'Kelly and Defense Minister Frank Aiken storming out of a diplomatic function at the French Legation when McNeill , the guest of honor , arrived , damaged Ó Ceallaigh 's reputation and image , particularly when the campaign backfired .
During this time he had been Minister for Local Government ( 1932-1939 ) and Minister for Finance ( 1939-1945 ) .
In 1906 he was elected to Dublin Corporation , which id Dublin 's city council .
In 1926 when de Valera left Sinn Féin to found his own republican party , Fianna Fáil , Ó Ceallaigh followed him , becoming one of the party 's founding members .
He was honorary secretary of the party from 1908 until 1925 .
In 1932 , when de Valera , was appointed President of the Executive Council ( prime minister ) of the Irish Free State he made Ó Ceallaigh Minister for Local Government .
O'Kelly died in Dublin .

Blessed art thou amongst women , and blessed is the fruit of thy womb , for thou hast given birth to the Saviour of our souls .
Holy Mary , Mother of God , pray for us sinners , now and at the hour of our death .
For translations from the Latin into various languages , see Wikisource .
Hail Mary , full of grace , the Lord is with thee ; blessed art thou among women , and blessed is the fruit of thy womb , Jesus .
The Hail Mary prayer used by the Eastern Orthodox Church and Eastern Catholic Churches is written : : Θεοτόκε Παρθένε , χαῖρε , κεχαριτωμένη Μαρία , ὁ Κύριος μετὰ σοῦ .
The text also appears in the story of the annunciation from the apocryphal Infancy Gospel of Matthew , in chapter 9 .
Even the earliest Western forms did not say anything like `` Mother of God and Virgin '' or `` for thou hast given birth to the Saviour of our souls '' , which are part of the Greek version .
So do many other groups within Christianity , including Anglicans , Independent Catholics , and Old Catholics .
The same thing can be translated differently into English : Mother of God and Virgin , rejoice , Mary full of grace , the Lord is with thee .
These new words asked Mary for help : `` Holy Mary , Mother of God , pray for us sinners now and at the hour of our death .
So do people who follow the Ruthenian recension ( like the Ukrainian Greek-Catholic Church and the Ruthenian Catholic Church ) .
This version is used by the Russian Orthodox Church , the Serbian Orthodox Church , the Bulgarian Orthodox Church and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church ) .
Eleven years later , this sentence was included in the Catechism of the Council of Trent of 1566 .
It is usually sung three times at the end of Vespers during an All-Night Vigil .
For this reason , both `` Hail '' and `` Rejoice '' are good English translations of the word .
In the way this phrase is written ( called the passive voice ) , the phrase means `` to have grace shown , or bestowed upon , one '' .
It also appears in several canons of prayer .
This phrase ( like all of Saint Luke 's Gospel ) was first written in Koine Greek .
The second is `` Blessed art thou amongst women and blessed is the fruit of thy womb '' ( Luke 1:42 ) .
This was a normal greeting in Koine Greek .
Hail Mary is a Christian prayer to Mary , the mother of Jesus .
The word κεχαριτωμένη , ( kecharitōménē ) is usually translated as `` full of grace '' .
In this prayer , a leader starts the prayer and others say the rest : In the Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Catholic Churches , the Hail Mary is very common .
A mechanism of interplay between the Yarkovsky effect and nonlinear secular resonances ( mainly involving Jupiter and Saturn ) has been suggested .
It is named after Lund Observatory , Sweden .
Assuming an albedo similar to 4 Vesta ( around 0.4 ) , suggests that the bodies are about 7 km across .
809 Lundia is a small , binary , V-type asteroid orbiting in the Flora family in the Main Belt .
It takes 15.4 hours to orbit each other , which says that the binary is very close - the separation being of the order of 10-20 km , if normal asteroid albedo and density values are assumed .
Its orbit is too far from Vesta for it to actually be a member of the Vesta family It is not clear how it came at an orbit so far from Vesta , but other examples of V-type asteroids fairly far from their parent body are known .
In fact , the size of the two bodies appear to be close in size , because during mutual occultations the brightness drops by a similar amount independently of which body is hidden .
The V-type spectrum says that it is not genetically related to the Flora family , but rather is probably a piece ( actually two pieces ) blown off the surface of nearby 4 Vesta by a big impact in the past .
Hovenia dulcis , the oriental raisin tree , is a plant which is native to Japan , Korea , Eastern China and the Himalayas .
The mother tries to force the baby to stop breastfeeding , and the baby tries to force the mother to continue .
Weaning conflict happens in several mammal species , including primates and canines .
When a baby does not drink any more breast milk ( or milk substitute ) , the baby has been weaned .

The geological period which corresponds to the Palaeolithic is the Pleistocene .

Bach , like many composers from long ago , did not use opus numbers , because very few of his works were published during his lifetime .

In the 2006 DVD documentary The Classic Artists Series : The Moody Blues ( DVD UK , released October 2006 ) , Mike Pinder , the former keyboard player of Birmingham R&B band The Moody Blues , states that the inspiration for the song actually rests with an incident that happened to them-a groupie climbing into an open bathroom window in the band 's home and spending the night with band member Ray Thomas .
The song was completed two days later with additional guitar and percussion .
`` She Came in Through the Bathroom Window '' is a song written by Paul McCartney ( although credited to Lennon\/McCartney ) and performed by The Beatles on their album Abbey Road as part of the Abbey Road medley .
McCartney said the song was inspired by Apple scruffs ( dedicated fans who would stay outside the Abbey Road studio and the homes of the Beatles ) , who broke into McCartney 's St John 's Wood home .
On July 28 , they added more vocals , guitar , percussion and piano .
She says that she was asked to get back a certain photograph , which she did .
The Beatles recorded the rhythm track for this and Polythene Pam as one piece on 25 July 1969 .
It took them 39 attempts , after which they added lead vocals and re-recorded the drums and bass guitar parts .
At the very beginning of the song , in anticipation to the change of meter , John Lennon says `` we 'll listen to that now ... heh-heh '' and then shouts `` Oh , look out ! ''
The next day , Pinder and Thomas told the story to McCartney , who-guitar in hand-strummed and sang `` She came in through the bathroom window ... '' .
She then opened the front door to let the others in , and they stole a number of photographs .
This song was performed directly after `` Polythene Pam '' , the song on the preceding track , without pause .

In 75 AD , XII Fulminata was in Caucasus , where Emperor Vespasian had sent the legion to support the allied kingdoms of Iberia and Albania .
The last 7000 Udi live mostly in the village of Nij of the region of Kabala and Oguz ( former Vartashen ) , but a few can be found in the capital Baku .
Among the facts that strengthen this hypothesis are the military-topoghraphical map of Caucasus published in 1903 by Russian Administration which spells name of town as `` Romana '' , various Roman artefacts found in the Absheron region and also old inhabitants ' referring to the town as Romani .
Additionally , Ramana is positioned in an area perfectly suited for a Roman `` castrum '' to control nearby Baku ' s port , on the commercial sea route ( through the Caspian sea ) between the Caucasus and the Central Asia plains .
During the third Perso-Turkic War , the Khazars ( Gokturks ) invaded Albania , and their leader Ziebel declared himself Lord of Albania in 627 AD under the Roman Heraclius rule , levying a tax on merchants and the fishermen of the Kura and Araxes rivers , which was `` in accordance with the land survey of the kingdom of Persia '' .
Emperor Nero prepared in 67 AD a military expedition in the Caucasus : he wanted to defeat the barbarian Alans and conquer for Rome all the northern shores of the Black sea from actual Georgia-Azerbaijan to what is now Romania-Moldavia , but his death stopped it .
In 35 AD King Pharasmanes of Iberia and his brother Mithridates , with the support of Rome , confronted the Parthians in Armenia : the Albanians proved effective allies , contributing to the defeat and temporary eviction of the Parthians .
After Armenia under Roman influence adopted Christianity as its state religion ( 301 AD ) , the Caucasian Albanian king Urnayr went to the See of the Armenian Apostolic Church to receive baptism from St. Gregory the Illuminator , the first `` Patriarch of Armenia '' .
Christianity reached its golden age in the late fifth century under Vachagan the Pious ( ruled 487-510 AD ) , who launched a campaign - influenced by Byzantine priests - against idol worship in Caucasian Albania and discouraged Persian Zoroastrianism .
Some historians argue that the actual settlement of Ramana near Baku was possibly founded by the Roman troops of Lucius Julius Maximus from `` Legio XII Fulminata '' in the first century AD and derives its name from the Latin Romana .
But fifty years later Rome lost the area that since then remained an integral part of the Sassanian Empire for more than two centuries .
Christianity started to enter Caucasian Albania , according to Movses Kaghankatvatsi , as early as during the 1st century , exactly when Romans imposed their initial control on Albania .
A king of Albania appears in the list of dynasties whose ambassadors were received by Augustus .
But the Albanians , influenced by the Parthian Empire were not slow to revolt against Rome : in 36 BC Mark Antony found himself obliged to send one of his lieutenants to bring an end to their rebellion .
Despite the growth of Roman influence , Albania never ceased to remain in commercial and probably also cultural contact with Persia , but with Trajan in 114 AD Roman control over Caucasian Albania was nearly complete with top social levels fully romanized .
The first Christian church in the region was built by St. Eliseus , a disciple of Thaddeus of Edessa , at a place called Gis and is believed to be the modern-day `` Church of Kish '' ) .
During the reign of Roman emperor Hadrian ( 117-138 ) Albania was invaded by the Alans , an Iranian nomadic group .
This invasion promoted an alliance between Rome and the Albanians that was reinforced under Antoninus Pius in 140 AD .
Caucasian Albania was later conquered by the Arabs in 643 AD , during the Islamic conquest of Persia .
In the late sixth century the territory of Albania became again an arena of wars between Sassanian Persia and the Byzantine\/Eastern Roman Empire .
Pompey ensured the control of Albanians nearly reaching the Caspian sea before returning to Anatolia .
Sassanians occupied the area around 240 Ad but after a few years the Roman Empire regained control of Caucasian Albania .
Zober , who was then king of Albania , capitulated and Albania thus became - at least in name - a `` Roman protectorate '' , starting a condition of vassalage that lasted for nearly three centuries .
The Albanian kings retained their rule by paying tribute to the regional powers .
After the Muslim invasions of the 7th century the original Christians have nearly disappeared from actual Azerbaijan .
The presence of a detachment of the Legio XII Fulminata at a distance of some kilometers from the shores of that sea ( 69 km south of Baku ) is attested by an inscription drawn up between 83 and 96 AD in the reign of Domitian .
In 297 AD the treaty of Nisibis stipulated the reestablishment of the Roman protectorate over Caucasian Iberia and Caucasian Albania .
An inscription has been found in Azerbaijan which reads : IMP DOMITIANO CAESARE AVG GERMANICO LVCIVS IVLIVS MAXIMVS LEGIONIS XII FVL , Under imperator Domitian , Caesar , Augustus Germanicus , Lucius Julius Maximus , Legio XII Fulminata .
Successively Vespasian was determined to restore and reinforce the full authority of Rome in the Caucasus as far as the Caspian .
A second and final influence came from the Eastern Roman Empire when emperor Heraclius was able to take control of Caucasian Albania in 627 AD with help from the Gokturks of the Western Turkic Khaganate , in the Third Perso-Turkic War .
In 65 BC , the Roman general Pompey , who had just subjugated Armenia and Iberia and had conquered Colchis , entered Albania at the head of his army .
Its influence over the region started in the first century before Christ and lasted until around 250 AD .
There was an enduring relation between Caucasian Albania and Ancient Rome .
The only remaining Caucasian Albanians are the Udi people , who maintain the Christian faith of their Roman influenced ancestors .
Rome controlled Caucasian Albania only as a client or vassal state .
In fording the Alazan river , he clashed with the forces of Oroezes , king of Albania , and eventually defeated them .
Around 299 AD , Albania was again a `` nominal '' vassal state of emperor Diocletianus for a few years more .

Under questioning Grace readily admitted that her story was untrue , and said she had been told what to say by Jane Southworth 's uncle , Christopher Southworth aka Thompson , a Jesuit priest who was in hiding in the Samlesbury area ; Southworth was the chaplain at Samlesbury Hall , and Jane Southworth 's uncle by marriage .
On being asked by the judge what answer they could make to the charges laid against them , Potts reports that they `` humbly fell upon their knees with weeping teares '' , and `` desired him ( Bromley ) for Gods cause to examine Grace Sowerbutts '' .
Bromley then committed the girl to be examined by two JPs , William Leigh and Edward Chisnal .
Leigh and Chisnal questioned the three accused women in an attempt to discover why Southworth might have fabricated evidence against them , but none could offer any reason other than that each of them `` goeth to the ( Anglican ) Church '' .
Bromley achieved his desired promotion to the Midlands Circuit in 1616 .
Jane Southworth 's eldest son , Thomas , eventually inherited his grandfather 's estate of Samlesbury Hall .
Immediately `` the countenance of this Grace Sowerbutts changed '' ; the witnesses `` began to quarrel and accuse one another '' , and eventually admitted that Grace had been coached in her story by a Catholic priest they called Thompson .
In 1618 , he was given responsibility for `` collecting the forfeitures on the laws concerning sewers , for twenty-one years '' .
One of the accused witches , Jane Southworth , was the widow of the disinherited son , John .
After the statements had been read out in court Bromley ordered the jury to find the defendants not guilty , stating that : Potts finished his book with the words : `` Thus were these poore Innocent creatures , by the great care and paines of this honorable Judge , delivered from the danger of this Conspiracie ; this bloudie practice of the Priest laid open '' .
By the early 1590s , he was convinced that Scottish witches plotted against him .
The case against the three women collapsed `` spectacularly '' when the main witness , Grace Sowerbutts , was shown by the trial judge to be `` the perjuring tool of a Catholic priest '' .
In early 1612 , the year of the trials , each justice of the peace ( JP ) in Lancashire was ordered to make a list of the recusants in their area-those who refused to attend the services of the Church of England , which was a criminal offence at that time .
Jane Southworth ( born Jane Sherburne ) and John were married in about 1598 , and the couple lived in Samlesbury Lower Hall .
Many historians , notably Hugh Trevor-Roper , have said that the witch trials of the 16th and 17th century were a result of the religious struggles of the period .
Since the death of Queen Mary and the coming to the throne of her half-sister Elizabeth in 1558 , Catholic priests had been forced to hide , but in remote areas like Lancashire they were still able to celebrate mass in secret .
At the end of the 16th century , the government thought this county was a wild and lawless area , `` fabled for its theft , violence and sexual laxity , where the church was honored without much understanding of its doctrines by the common people '' .
His 1597 book , Daemonologie , he told his followers that they must report and prosecute any supporters or practitioners of witchcraft .
The trial of the Samlesbury witches is perhaps one clear example of that trend ; it has been described as `` largely a piece of anti-Catholic propaganda '' , .
Thomas Potts , the clerk , wrote that after hearing the evidence many of those in court were persuaded of the accused 's guilt .
James was , did not believe some of the evidence presented in witch trials , he even personally showed discrepancies in the testimonies presented against some accused witches .
This event split up the Southworth family of Samlesbury Hall .
Their trial on 19 August 1612 was one of a series of witch trials held over two days .
John had died only a few months before her trial for witchcraft in 1612 , and she had seven children .
In contrast , other people tried at the same time were accused of maleficium , that is causing harm by witchcraft .
King James I , came to the English throne in 1603 .
First , Thomas Potts , the clerk to the court , wrote about it in his The Wonderfull Discoverie of Witches in the Countie of Lancaster .
The three women were Jane Southworth , Jennet Bierley , and Ellen Bierley .
His eldest son , also called John , did join the Church of England , for which his father disinherited him .
In 1604 a new witchcraft law was made , called `` An Act against Conjuration , Witchcraft and dealing with evil and wicked spirits '' .
Relations father and son were not polite ; John Singleton , said that the father would not even go passed his son 's house if he could keep clear of it , and believed that Jane would probably kill her husband .
Sir John Southworth , head of the family until his death in 1595 , was a leading recusant .
Samuel James `` Sam '' Champion ( born August 13 , 1961 ) is the weather anchor of ABC 's Good Morning America and weather editor of ABC News .
Champion was born in Paducah , Kentucky .
He has a B.A. in broadcast journalism from Eastern Kentucky University .
Champion is active in many charitable organizations in the New York City area including the National Multiple Sclerosis Society , March of Dimes , and `` Stopping AIDS Together '' .
On April 7 , 2012 , he debuted as host of Sea Rescue , an educational and informational television program that focuses on the rescue , rehabilitation , and release of animals back into the wild .
Champion and his longtime partner Rubem Robierb were married on December 21 , 2012 .

It arrived in Philadelphia in August 1752 .
Isaac Norris , speaker of the Pennsylvania Provincial Assembly , ordered the colony 's London agent , Robert Charles , to get a `` good Bell of about two thousands pound weight '' .
The bell became widely famous after a short story in 1847 claimed that an old bell-ringer rang it on July 4 , 1776 , after hearing the Second Continental Congress 's vote for independence .
From the 1885 , the City of Philadelphia , which owned the bell , allowed it to go to many different patriotic meetings .
Bells were rung when the Declaration of Independence was read on July 8 , 1776 .
The first bell hung from a tree behind the Pennsylvania State House , now known as Independence Hall .
The bell was ordered from the London firm of Lester and Pack ( which is known as the Whitechapel Bell Foundry today ) in 1752 .

The mountain was named after Sir William Edmond Logan , a Canadian geologist and founder of the Geological Survey of Canada ( GSC ) .
Temperatures are extremely low on and near Mount Logan .
Little snow melt leads to a large ice cap , reaching almost 300 m ( 984 ft ) in certain spots .
Mount Logan is in Kluane National Park and Reserve in southwestern Yukon .
It is the second-highest peak in North America , after Mount McKinley ( Denali ) .
On the 5,000 m high plateau , air temperature stays around − 45 ° C ( − 49 ° F ) in the winter .
Logan is believed to have the largest base circumference of any non-volcanic mountain on Earth .

The ultraparallel theorem states that there is a unique line in the hyperbolic plane that is perpendicular to each of a given pair of ultraparallel lines .
In 1868 , Eugenio Beltrami provided models of it , and used this to prove that hyperbolic geometry was consistent if Euclidean geometry was .
There are three models commonly used for hyperbolic geometry : the Klein model , the Poincaré disc model , and the Lorentz model , or hyperboloid model .
Lobachevsky published in 1830 , while Bolyai independently discovered it and published in 1832 .
These models define a real hyperbolic space which satisfies the axioms of a hyperbolic geometry .
In Euclidean geometry , the angle of parallelism is a constant ; that is , any distance between parallel lines yields an angle of parallelism equal to 90 ° .
The term `` hyperbolic geometry '' was introduced by Felix Klein in 1871 .
In the nineteenth century , hyperbolic geometry was explored by János Bolyai and Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky , after whom it sometimes is named .
In this article , the two limiting lines are called asymptotic and lines that have a common perpendicular are called ultraparallel ; the simple word parallel may apply to both .
Their attempts failed , but their efforts gave birth to hyperbolic geometry .
Thus , as distances get smaller , the hyperbolic plane behaves more and more like Euclidean geometry .
Because there is no hyperbolic analog to Euclidean parallel lines , the hyperbolic use of parallel and related terms varies among writers .
In hyperbolic geometry , the angle of parallelism varies with the function .
Karl Friedrich Gauss also studied hyperbolic geometry , describing in a 1824 letter to Taurinus that he had constructed it , but did not publish his work .
This function , described by Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky , produces a unique angle of parallelism for each distance .
Symmetrically , the line y that forms the same angle θ between PB and itself but clockwise from PB will also be asymptotic .
Thus we have this modified form of the parallel postulate : In hyperbolic geometry , given any line l , and point P not on l , there are exactly two lines through P which are asymptotic to l , and infinitely many lines through P ultraparallel to l. The differences between these types of lines can also be looked at in the following way : the distance between asymptotic lines run to zero in one direction and grows without bound in the other ; the distance between ultraparallel lines increases in both directions .
An interesting property of hyperbolic geometry follows from the occurrence of more than one parallel line through a point P : there are two classes of non-intersecting lines .
Indeed , on small scales compared to , where is the ( constant ) Gaussian curvature of the plane , an observer would have a hard time determining whether he is in the Euclidean or the hyperbolic plane .
Despite the naming , the two disc models and the half-plane model were introduced as models of hyperbolic space by Beltrami , not by Poincaré or Klein .
Let B be the point on l such that the line PB is perpendicular to l. Consider the line x through P such that x does not intersect l , and the angle θ between PB and x counterclockwise from PB is as small as possible ; i.e. , any smaller angle will force the line to intersect l. This is called an asymptotic line in hyperbolic geometry .
Models have been constructed within Euclidean geometry that obey the axioms of hyperbolic geometry .
The parallel postulate in Euclidean geometry says that in two dimensional space , for any given line l and point P not on l , there is exactly one line through P that does not intersect l. This line is called parallel to l. In hyperbolic geometry there are at least two such lines through P. As they do not intersect l , the parallel postulate is false .
x and y are the only two lines asymptotic to l through P. All other lines through P not intersecting l , with angles greater than θ with PB , are called ultraparallel ( or disjointly parallel ) to l. Notice that since there are an infinite number of possible angles between θ and 90 degrees , and each one will determine two lines through P and disjointly parallel to l , there exist an infinite number of ultraparallel lines .
In mathematics , hyperbolic geometry is a non-Euclidean geometry , meaning that the parallel postulate of Euclidean geometry is replaced .
Their works on hyperbolic geometry had a influence on its development among later European geometers , including Witelo , Alfonso and John Wallis .
The theorems of Alhacen , Khayyam on quadrilaterals , were the first theorems on hyperbolic geometry .
As the distance gets shorter , approaches 90 ° , whereas with increasing distance approaches 0 ° .
A number of geometers made attempts to prove the parallel postulate , including Omar Khayyám , and later Giovanni Gerolamo Saccheri , John Wallis , Lambert , and Legendre .
